column1: 121071,OPEN,Integrated terminal becomes very laggy on Ubuntu via remote ssh,,2021-04-12 06:59:54 +0000 UTC,renkun-ken,,"
To narrow down the problem, I tried the following:
1. Locally, printing the table is very fast.
2. In a local vscode, open the integrated terminal and ssh to the server and start R, and print `mtcars`. It is very fast too.
3. Use remote ssh to connect to the server. Open the integrated terminal and start R and print `mtcars`. It is very laggy, i.e. the printing is almost done line by line.

The typing in the integrated terminal is laggy too. In current release (1.55.1), I need to switch to `""terminal.integrated.rendererType"": ""canvas""` so that typing is no longer laggy. In current insider, the setting is gone, and I have to use `""terminal.integrated.gpuAcceleration"": ""off""` and the laggy typing is fixed. However, in both cases, while the laggy typing is fixed, the laggy printing via remote ssh still persists.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
On Opening the terminal, I am getting weird spaces which makes the terminal look so unpresentable and I cannot work on it.

121055,OPEN,language server diagnostic dialogs should hint at what the (number) is,,2021-04-11 17:50:45 +0000 UTC,jsoref,,Chrome: 87.0.4280.141
1. Install ms-azuretools.vscode-docker 1.11.0 (newer versions will fix this specific flavor which means you'd have to find your own language server alert)
2. Create a Dockerfile with the content from https://github.com/check-spelling/check-spelling/blob/ce3aff0bfdf1cbabeffecb5afc28cf6b1c719e25/Dockerfile#L17-L22
5. It isn't readily apparent what `(34)` is or why there's no space between it and `dockerfile-utils`.

I suppose I should define `is`. Both views already tell me what the warning is. They do not explain why they also show `(34)`. Letting one hover over this or click to see a hint indicating that this is a language-server specific identifier for this warning category would be quite elucidating.

For instance, can I use the `(34)` to ignore the alert? I have no idea. Maybe I can, but only for certain language servers? These views are a good way to teach me what I can do w/ the content they're presenting.

Also, while you're in the area, if there was a way to cause `dockerfile-utils` to explain which extension(s) contributed it, that'd be really helpful. I eventually figured out that I wanted to file a bug against microsoft/vscode-docker, but it wasn't remotely obvious.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
No (well, you need a language server, and I don't know if vscode has any built in)
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
This bug isn't about the language server (I already filed microsoft/vscode-docker#2865 about their contribution), it's about vscode's rendering of the report from the language server:
Fwiw, I currently use the reporter format for my GitHub Action, and at some point, I might look into making it available as a vscode extension, since I'm starting to live here, as do my colleagues.
GitHub Actions, afaict, do not render the identifier:

121043,OPEN,Keyboard-only context-switching and scrolling in Python Interactive,,2021-04-11 11:07:31 +0000 UTC,nayefahmad,,"At this point, the outputs in the Python Interactive window look like this:
So let's say I want to do the following:
1. Switch from the .py file to the Python Interactive window using only the keyboard.
2. Scroll up using the keyboard to view the output of `df.head()`.
3. Switch back to the .py file and write more code, using only the keyboard.
There doesn't seem to be any way to do this. I can switch to the Python Interactive window using `Ctrl + 2`, but it goes to the console input, and I can't scroll the previous outputs.

Avoiding use of the mouse for scrolling and switching windows is a very important accessibility issue for me. At present I find VS Code almost unusable for interactive analysis because of lack of support for keyboard-only workflows.
I am using VS Code on Windows. Some additional details:

121028,OPEN,Simple Browser not working when running from source,,2021-04-10 23:08:29 +0000 UTC,gjsjohnmurray,,"Steps to reproduce:
1. Build VS Code from source using Insiders
2. Launch Code - OSS Dev, either from Debug or from `.\scripts\code`
3. Open Command Palette, run `Simple Browser: Show` and enter a URL such as http://localhost
Toolbar icons are missing and page doesn't load.

Resolve the problem by copying `codicon.css`, `codicon.ttf` and `index.js` into the extensions\simple-browser\media folder from `C:\Users\XXX\AppData\Local\Programs\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\resources\app\extensions\simple-browser\media`
Presumably the build task is missing a step.

121018,OPEN,VS Code cannot start without internet,new release,2021-04-10 17:22:26 +0000 UTC,bleakley,,"- VS Code Version: 1.55.1
1. When internet is on, VS Code detects an update.
Updating VS Code Server to version 08a217c4d27a02a5bcde898fd7981bda5b49391b
Installing VS Code Server for x64 (08a217c4d27a02a5bcde898fd7981bda5b49391b)
Resolving update.code.visualstudio.com (update.code.visualstudio.com)... failed: Temporary failure in name resolution.
wget: unable to resolve host address ‘update.code.visualstudio.com’
5. Try to start it without updating, realize you don't know what, if any, command line flag will launch it without updating.
7. Realize you can't even view the view available options because you can't start it without updating.
8. Realize you can't google how to start it because the internet is disconnected.

This is 100% unambiguously a bug. I'm aware it's possible to disable this behavior within VS Code. The user needs to be able to disable this on the command line, and the user needs to be able to view the help on the command line whether or not the internet is available.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

,,

121006,OPEN,Add desktop.ini to the default files.exclude list,,2021-04-10 11:07:53 +0000 UTC,tpiekarski,,  ""**/CVS"": true,
**I would like to ask if we could add desktop.ini (and maybe thumbs.db as well) to this default list?**

desktop.ini files are created by the Windows Explorer when you customize a directory (for example adding a custom icon). For details please refer to [How to Customize Folders with Desktop.ini](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/shell/how-to-customize-folders-with-desktop-ini).
This file is imho a counterpart to the already added .DS_Store used on macOS.
> In the Apple macOS operating system, .DS_Store is a file that stores custom attributes of its containing folder, such as the position of icons or the choice of a background image.
**Should you agree with me, I would like to provide this little PR as my first one** 😃",,

> In order to resolve the EADDRINUSE issue I just manually killed the port so that I can run my node js application. Now my terminal is able to run my app and I got a message Express server listening on port 8000.

Maybe you had a left over process running from a previous time that you ran your application? The terminal is just a terminal, so if you get an error when running that command then it isn't coming from VS Code.

column1: 120991,OPEN,Support for tri-state boolean in settings UI,,2021-04-10 04:10:10 +0000 UTC,bobbrow,,"  ""ext.setting1"": true,
so we end up using synonyms like 'enabled', 'disabled', 'default' which is less than ideal.

Another approach would be to use ""oneOf"" and have the choices be type: boolean and type:string with a single enum value.  This gets the desired effect when editing the JSON directly, but unfortunately, we don't get Settings UI support when we try that.
Could we get a new type for configurations, or maybe some kind of UI support for tri-state bools? We'd be fine with whatever syntax would be required for package.json.

column1: 120981,OPEN,Arrow down always reveals list item bottom when the item is taller than render height,under-discussion,2021-04-09 21:42:12 +0000 UTC,rebornix,,"

Say we have 4 items in a list view, the viewport can only render 3 complete item and the 4th one is partially visible. The height of the 4th item is taller than the render height (or visual viewport). Now focus the 3rd item and then arrow down. The list view will scroll the bottom of the 4th cell into view so the top half of the 4th item is not visible. I wonder we should try the best to make sure the top of cell is visible when users pressing `arrow down`.

column1: 120980,OPEN,MacOS (x86) binary not in PATH after restart,,2021-04-09 22:07:51 +0000 UTC,marklabrecque,,"
1. Run the command ""Install code in PATH"" from the command palette.
2. Check the terminal, it should find the 'code' binary.
3. Restart the computer and check again - ""command not found: code""
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

It looks like running that command palette operation mentioned above adds a symlink to the /usr/local/bin directory, which is what I would expect it to do. However, the target of the symlink is a bit odd. I just checked and I see the following in /usr/local/bin:

Once rebooting, it looks like the symlink target is no longer a valid path. In my case, when I rebooted, the path segment after AppTranslocation changed to a different UUID, but the rest of the PATH looked correct.

A workaround for now was for me to manually add the following entry to my PATH env var: /Applications/Visual\ Studio\ Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/bin which of course persists over a reboot, as it is a direct link to where the application lives.
Feel free to contact me for more information/details @ mark.labrecque@gmail.com

column1: 120969,OPEN,yarn.lock entries from `https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/` cause integrity errors during yarn install,,2021-04-10 16:54:50 +0000 UTC,Livven,,"This issue is related to the repository itself, not a user-facing bug.

error https://registry.yarnpkg.com/node-fetch/-/node-fetch-2.6.1.tgz: Integrity check failed for ""node-fetch"" (computed integrity doesn't match our records, got ""sha512-fj8mVcK9LJT4SvIu55ISid8MunMHFLVOMbYiR90ijFWMukEOuqmkUH+eLojFw6uOHX+aN4ISiBXCm8RSnvkUmg== sha1-cdo97ykvwhrcVnCCVGHqNsMWZDw="")

error https://registry.yarnpkg.com/before-after-hook/-/before-after-hook-2.1.0.tgz: Integrity check failed for ""before-after-hook"" (computed integrity doesn't match our records, got ""sha512-Y/5OWH5dwPeVDsynDPGyvfbq2ZSg/Kll4huL+kgzDrTe8KF2rfGJ8AkvQkPQNijY0uXgsT4ESbuJ/mPJf980Hw== sha1-C7ViU5yYr2R5w+Qj3xiA0CK9nHY="")

Now, I can't actually reproduce this on my local machine, and judging by the lack of other reports it seems no one else can either. However this has been reproducibly happening in our CI infrastructure (which is behind a corporate proxy etc.) 🤷‍♀️

The root cause is two yarn.lock entries that resolve to `https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/` rather than `https://registry.yarnpkg.com/`, which seems like an oversight that should be corrected anyway. See #120970 for details and fix.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

120953,OPEN,git.autorefresh user setting being overridden by default workspace setting,new release,2021-04-10 17:03:34 +0000 UTC,bdharrington7,,

This started happening on a recent update of VSCode, where git autofetch was triggering (I get prompted for credentials on every check), despite the git.autorefresh setting being disabled in User settings. When I view the workspace settings, git.autofetch is enabled (by default), so when I disable it, the `.vscode/settings.json` file is modified with the key `git.autorefresh: false`

If the User setting is set, and the workspace setting is *not* set (even if the default is ""enabled""), shouldn't the feature be disabled unless the feature is explicitly enabled in the workspace settings (I understand workspace settings override user settings)?

column1: 120943,OPEN,iPad: read mode should be the default,feature-request; ios,2021-04-09 18:00:12 +0000 UTC,isidorn,,"iPad, safari or Chrome
As soon as you tap on the editor and focus is moved into the editor the keyboard is shown below thus reducing screen real estate.
I believe that the best experience for an iPad would be that the keyboard appearing would be a much more explicit gesture.
This is because I also believe that most of the iPad use case is code reading, not actually code writing.
I think we could tackle this by:
* Make all editors readonly by default on ipad, and there is a specific user action to make them read write
* Be more careful when automatically pasing focus to the editor, and try to not do this at all on an iPad
Or if there are other tricks for this? I do not think a web page can disable a on screen keyboard.

120906,OPEN,Terminal tabs panel issues,bug; integrated-terminal; integrated-terminal-tabs,2021-04-09 11:29:01 +0000 UTC,joaomoreno,,Some early feedback since I accidentally enabled this with the setting:
- [ ] Left pane needs a higher minimum width, or a better overflow behavior. You can even remove the left padding from each row, to get more space there.

- [ ] Growing/shrinking the splitview should not use the proportional resizing. We should use [different layout priorities](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/e1f0f8f51390dea5df9096718fb6b647ed5a9534/src/vs/base/browser/ui/splitview/splitview.ts#L40-L47) to make sure the left pane doesn't shrink when the entire workbench shrinks, unless absolutely necessary, similar to the workbench sidebar.

- [ ] We should probably use the new [`selectionNavigation`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/e1f0f8f51390dea5df9096718fb6b647ed5a9534/src/vs/platform/list/browser/listService.ts#L196-L196) setting to prevent focus from being different from selection
- [ ] Right click on list, `New Terminal`, 🐛 all list items are selected. Same if you toggle the setting off/on.

,,
120902,OPEN,Electron: crash reporter slows down startup,perf; perf-startup; workbench-diagnostics,2021-04-09 07:40:06 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,There is a new perf mark to measure the impact of the crash reporter on the startup which is a sync blocking call.

column1: 120882,OPEN,Copy/Paste a file in explorer window has recently broken the editor file focus,file-explorer; under-discussion,2021-04-12 02:07:44 +0000 UTC,klueless-io,,"Issue Type: Bug
When  I clone a file, the focus for the file has always been the cloned file and so I can start editing that file and straight away.

This behaviour has changed in the last couple of weeks, I have nearly lost valuable code multiple times recently because of this behaviour change and had thought I was doing something wrong, but I have reproduction steps listed below.
I have tested this without extensions turned on `code --disable-extensions` to rule out issues there.
The following keystrokes (on mac) is a flow that I have been using for years to work on the next (new) class or file in vscode, this flow has recently stopped working as expected.
I have a file opened, I'll call it `original.rb` and it is finished and I am ready to move onto my next class/file.
Here are the keystrokes and mouse clicks that I do.
Command+Shift+E  - This selects the explorer window
Command+C        - This copies the current file 'original.rb'
Command+V.       - This pastes the current file to 'original copy.rb'
At this point, the focus in the explorer window is the cloned file 'original copy.rb'  and up until recently the focus in the editor has also been the cloned file 'original copy.rb'
I now click mouse in the open editor window
BUG: This is not the case any more, the original file has the focus in the editor, even though the cloned file has focus in the explorer .

What has happened time-after-time in the last week or two is that I click into the editor with the assumption that I am working on the cloned file, I update it, delete irrelevant methods,  add new methods, save my code and then go to run and my build is failing because I was not  altering the cloned file, instead I have been destroying the original file.
I've checked the autoReveal settings to see if there was an issue there, but I can't see any issues.

column1: File opens in Notebook Editor when double-clicked

5. add a character somewhere to break the file.
6. Try opening it in Notebook editor. Doesn't work (this is expected).

8. Try opening in Notebook editor. Doesn't work. (it's a new file so this is unexpected)

120839,OPEN,VSCode extension can't start external Electron application,,2021-04-08 15:11:23 +0000 UTC,AndriiCloud,,
1. use `vscode.env.openExternal()` for running external Electron App.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported direct to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
In scope of Linux OS (Ubuntu) new extension for vscode can't start external Electron app.
Node methods 'child_process' are not [effective](https://www.electronjs.org/docs/api/window-open). They can start main process without window, so UI doesn't work.
Running Electron application using vscode method 'vscode.env.openExternal()' without results.
At the same time method 'vscode.env.openExternal()' works fine for Windows and MacOS.",,

120837,OPEN,[Feature - Additional CLI API] A way to invoke extension functions / internal calls (basically anything you can currently run through the command palette) in a headless manner for use with automated setup and build processes,,2021-04-08 15:58:10 +0000 UTC,MostHated,,"Hey there,

I have been trying everything under the sun that I can find in order to accomplish this, but have yet to find anything that works. I have been looking for a way to invoke extension functions / internal calls (basically anything you can currently run through the command palette) in a headless manner for use with automated setup and build processes. Similar to how you can run `code --install-extension ext.name.here` but expanded to allow for once an extension is installed, to be able to invoke one of the extensions commands directly using the same text string that would be used to run it from the command palette or when creating a new hotkey. An example being `code --run-command extensionname.extensioncommand` or `code --run-command task.taskname`, etc.

Following the documentation i created a .env file to create a name for docker compose.

120826,OPEN,extensions view: Wrap stars instead of clipping them,,2021-04-08 13:14:11 +0000 UTC,jsoref,,![stars clipped](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2119212/114026076-d2b15580-9843-11eb-9fa3-407889330f26.png)
2 stars doesn't seem like a good rating. But I installed it anyway. (Yes, it has 3+ stars, but ...)

Keep in mind that a user, like me, won't necessarily know how non present stars work. Sure, it's possible that they're painted as hollow (as VSCode does), but it's also possible that they're painted as invisible, and if a user doesn't see them, and hasn't looked for extensions in general / recently, there's no way for them to know.
stars aren't shown in this view, so there's no hint about how to expect them above:
Some parts of the top grow ellipses, and the descriptive content wraps:
![ellipsis for short desc and wrapping in README](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2119212/114026755-9c280a80-9844-11eb-8f8c-6108e8c8f364.png)

In short, I'd like the stars to wrap as an integral unit. arguably whatever `tht13.html-preview-vscode` is and the non selectable text _This extension is enabled globally._  should as well. Or, if not, at least use ellipses instead of simply clipping them.",,

120825,OPEN,Terminal inserts strange characters when pressing Ctrl R,bug; integrated-terminal; integrated-terminal-local-echo,2021-04-12 03:35:20 +0000 UTC,joaomoreno,,"This started pretty recently: when I use <kbd>Ctrl R</kbd> to access my shell history in fzf, the VS Code terminal _sometimes_ inserts `1R1R` right after the sequence, which messes up its usage.
This doesn't repro on a fresh new terminal, but as soon as I run something like `docker ps`, it starts reproducing always.
I can't repro this in stable 1.54, but I can definitely repro on the new stable 1.55, so this can definitely be a candidate, given it's a regression.

120810,OPEN,Terminal buffer doesn't span full width,,2021-04-11 15:07:08 +0000 UTC,oliversalzburg,,
When VS Code opens, the usable buffer of the terminal will be severely truncated in width. Using the terminal beyond the limited width, will result in display corruption:

Closing the terminal and opening it again, restores the buffer to full width. This is very cumbersome, as logging out from the terminal often produces an error message that has to be manually closed as well, before ultimately opening the terminal in its desired state.

When _restoring_ the window down from maximized state, the terminal buffer fits perfectly into the new bounds of the window. This suggests that this restored window size (or VSCs handling of window state during startup) is also the reason for this glitch.

column1: 120803,OPEN,Consider to cache debugger's inline values on scrolling,debug; feature-request,2021-04-08 08:51:06 +0000 UTC,weinand,,"For details see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/119559#issuecomment-815558790
I'm developing a doodba-based project (Odoo + docker-compose).
While trying to debug, the 1st time will take about 15s to connect to the debugger. The developer console says:
WARN UNRESPONSIVE extension host, 'vscode.git' took 95% of 5664.741ms, saved PROFILE here: 'file:///tmp/exthost-14a0ee.cpuprofile'

I cannot test this without extensions because I need the python extension to debug python and reproduce the problem. However, AFAICS the unresponsiveness comes from git, which AFAIK is bundled with vscode.
After that is logged, if I debug again, it will connect immediately, as expected.

120773,OPEN,Rename file with ""Git: Rename"" not working ?",,2021-04-08 15:49:23 +0000 UTC,moocan,,"

2. Renamed file is marked as a `deleted (untracked)` file and as a `new (untracked)` file
Using directly in git repository `git mv fileoldname filenewname` has a different behavior.
File is marked as `renamed (staged)` and not as `deleted (untracked)` and `new (untracked)`.

I found this closed issue [Rename file with ""Git: Rename""](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/93299) but it is locked (and all related issues are closed too) and I cannot find any documentation on it.

It seems that the pull request [97486](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/97486/commits/31ee5b96449103913998a073686fe69f1f6e3eef) has been marged on November 2020, but I don't  find any `git context menu` or `Git: Rename` anywhere (even with ctrl+shift+P) but only the standard `Rename file` (even inside a valid Git repository which is at the root of the workspaceFolder and seen by Visual Studio Code Source Control).

column1: 120711,OPEN,Improve creation of launch.json JSON scheme,debt; debug; help wanted,2021-04-07 15:33:40 +0000 UTC,weinand,,"Today the JSON scheme for the launch.json is dynamically created from all debug extension contributions and predefined common propoerties. This results in a typical size of 42000 lines.

Most of these lines are duplicated because the schema has 3 sub-schemas for the platform sections ""osx"", ""windows"", and ""linux"". Instead of replicating the schema 3 times, we should use JSON's reference mechanism `$ref`.
With this approach we could easily bring down the size to 14000 lines.

Another area for improvement are the duplicated predefined properties. Instead of duplicating them into every sub-schema, we could try to make the sub-schema inherit from some base schema. But it could be that this is not possible in JSON schema.

,,

120680,OPEN,Assigning undefined to commentThread.contextValue doesn't reset the backing context key,comments,2021-04-08 19:59:34 +0000 UTC,hunterknepshield,,"1. From `package.json`, have a menu contribution registered for `comments/commentThread/context` to show some command with `""when"": ""commentThread != sentinelForPackageJson""`
3. Leave the thread's `contextValue` unassigned for now
4. Observe that the command from `package.json` is currently visible in a comment thread; type a reply and click the button for that command

5. Within the handling code for that command, assign the thread's `contextValue` to `""sentinelForPackageJson""` (similar to the example extension in `microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/main/comment-sample/src/extension.ts` when handling `mywiki.startDraft`). My extension also sets the thread's `canReply` value to `false` at the same time.

6. Have another command to effectively discard the comment created with the prior command. It will set the thread's `canReply` value to `true` and set its `contextValue` to `undefined`. Observe that in this case, the command from 1 is not rendered, but the textbox to type a reply has reappeared.

I've been playing around with it, and if instead of setting the `contextValue` to undefined in step 6, I set some other random arbitrary value, then the context key is updated correctly and the command does reappear. I believe it has something to do with the slight difference in `commentThreadWidget.ts`, specifically around `_commentThreadContextValue`:

Using the inspect context keys tool, the `commentThread` context key is still set to `""sentinelForPackageJson""`, even though the object's property is definitely `undefined` after the command in 6 runs. For some reason, it seems the lifecycle of the comment thread is latching on to `""sentinelForPackageJson""` as the default value, even though it wasn't assigned anywhere near the thread's creation time, and was only done so later after user action had taken place + the thread was updated to append a new comment.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

column1: TS 4.3 adds a new strictness option: [`--noImplicitOverride`](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/39669). This requires that you use the `override` keyword when overriding and method:
To fix this, simply add the `override` keyword:
The override keyword does not change runtime behavior but can help programmers in a few ways:
- When reading code, it alerts you that a method is overriding one from the base class

- It is an error to try to override a method that does not exist on the base class. This can help catch errors caused by renaming a method in a base class but forgetting to update the method name in the subclasses.
I propose enabling this new flag for both VS Code code and extensions.

Enabling it currently causes ~2200 compile errors, however unlike the previous strictness checks we enabled, I believe should simply use a script to automatically fix the vast majority of them (by inserting `override` in the necessary location)",,

120639,OPEN,Commit (Amend) doesn't change the commit message if there are no staged changes but there are changes,,2021-04-06 15:08:49 +0000 UTC,Maxpxt,,
1. Open vscode on a git repository.
2. Do some changes, but don't stage anything.
3. In the SCM view, write a commit message in the input field then select ""Commit > Commit All (Amend)"" or ""Commit > Commit Staged (Amend)"" in the context menu from the ""..."" icon.
The expected behavior is for the message of the last commit to be updated.
What actually happens is nothing. The message of the last commit is not updated and no command is shown in the git output tab.

Note that when there are staged changes or when there are no changes at all, staged and not staged, ""Commit > Commit All (Amend)"" does update the message as expected. It only does nothing when there are changes, but no staged changes.

column1: 120633,OPEN,[new-feature] History File,,2021-04-07 12:09:25 +0000 UTC,AlexandroGonSan,,"3. na barra lateral esquerda deve ser colocado uma segunda coluna após a coluna de collapse e expand brackets. Essa coluna a ser adicionada deve ser idêntica a coluna que já existe para arquivos git versionados. Essa barra deve permanecer após a coluna collapse e expand brackets mesmo se nunca tiver sido feito um commit desse arquivo ou a pasta desse arquivo não for um repositório git desde que tenha algum commit desse arquivo no repositório code.git
4. Essa feature deve funcionar se estiver habilitada mesmo se a feature de salvar automático estiver habilitada.
5. Essa feature deve ser fornecida desabilitada por padrão.
6. Deve-se informar nas release notes das versões insider e stable que a feature está disponível com apresentação de uso com gifs animados como ocorre para outras features.
1. create a hidden folder in the directory of the file named code.git and start the git repositorio of that folder

2. whenever the file is saved, copy it to the code.git folder and perform the ""git add file & git commit -m ""${msg}"". msg must be configured in settings.json with the right to various parameters, which involve the Code and the file, such as code version, otherwise some standard message should be generated'

3. In the left sidebar should be placed a second column after the collapse column and expand brackets. This column to be added must be identical to the column that already exists for versioned git files. This bar should remain after the collapse column and expand brackets even if this file has never been committed, or the folder of that file is not a git repository as long as it has some commit of that file in the code.git repository
4. This feature should work if it is enabled even if the auto save feature is enabled.
5. This feature should be provided disabled by default.
6. It should be informed in the release notes of the insider and stable versions that the feature is available with presentation of use with animated gifs as occurs for other features.

column1: 120618,OPEN,Small user snippet issue using single quotes,snippets,2021-04-06 10:16:40 +0000 UTC,thomv-dev,,"I noticed this issue happening after the February update (I think). I'll try to explain this the best way I can. When I want to insert single quotes ' ', I press the single quote button once and 2 quotes appear. The cursor/pointer is inbetween those 2 quotes. After pressing backspace/delete, both of the quotes dissapear again. This is expected behaviour.
Now, I use a snippet to print a console.log line, like so:

My cursor starts at `$1`, so in between the quotes. When I want to remove both quotes by pressing backspace once, only the left one deletes. This used to work like mentioned above, where both single quotes would be removed.
When I try to manually write `console.log('');`, go in between the quotes and press delete, both of the quotes go away, which is expected behaviour. So I guess the issue lies in the snippet quotes.
As you see, when using the snippet and pressing delete afterwards, only the left one removes, instead of both. After manually typing quotes, they both delete when pressing backspace.

120617,OPEN,API Request: onDidChangeTextDocument - differentiate between user input and redo/undo,api; editor-core; feature-request,2021-04-07 16:13:03 +0000 UTC,hediet,,The extension API of VS Code 1.54.3 offers the event `workspace.onDidChangeTextDocument` that can be used to subscribe to text changes.
Currently, it does not seem to be possible to differentiate between text changes caused by user-input and those caused by redo/undo.
This is problematic if an extension wants to use the `onDidChangeTextDocument` event to modify the document when certain characters are typed by the user.
For example, the abbreviation rewrite feature of the Lean VS Code extension makes use of it (if the user types `\alpha` it gets replaced by `α` immediately).

However, if the user undoes and redoes their changes, `onDidChangeTextDocument` is also triggered. When undoing/redoing, new text edits are very harmful though, [as they destroy the redo stack](https://github.com/leanprover/vscode-lean/issues/259). Thus, extensions must not modify the document on redos/undos.
If `redos` cannot be differentiated from user input, this problem cannot be avoided if an extension wants to modify the document on certain text changes.
It would be helpful if VS Code could provide a reason that caused the text change.
* `unknown`: E.g. caused by liveshare or use of workspace.applyEdit
The reason could be provided by the `TextDocumentChangeEvent`:
/** The text change is caused by extensions or other unknown sources. */
/** The text change is caused by the user editing the document. */
/** The text change is caused as part of an redo operation. */
/** The text change is caused as part of an undo operation. */
* An event describing a transactional [document](#TextDocument) change.

120585,OPEN,Iteration Plan for April 2021,iteration-plan,2021-04-06 18:29:51 +0000 UTC,kieferrm,,This plan captures our work in **April**. This is a 5-week iteration. We will ship in **early May**.
The endgame details for this iteration are tracked [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Aendgame-plan+milestone%3A%22April+2021%22).
Below is a summary of the top level plan items.

column3: more investigation required to remove uncertainty
a large work item, larger than one iteration

column1: - [ ] :runner: Provide documentation for extension authors on adoption and testing
- [ ] Improve UX of completed and hidden items and the recent workspaces list @jacksonkearl @misolori
- [ ] :runner: Explore extension contributions to the ""New File..."" item @misolori
- [ ] Allow markdown-based content in Getting Started pages https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/120050, https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/119709 @jacksonkearl
- [ ] Allow display of Getting Started pages on extension install @jacksonkearl
- [ ] :muscle: Explore integration of release notes and extension changelogs @jacksonkearl
- [ ] :runner: Continue user testing on new welcome pages @digitarald

Create a file with a non-capital first letter (ex. ""settingsButton.js"").  Open the file in vscode.  Now, rename the file within vscode, now capitalizing the first letter (""settingsButton.js"" -> ""SettingsButton.js"").  Vscode will now say that there is no file with the name you are trying to open.  I'm guessing this is because vscode does not store files as case specific, which seems like a larger issue.  Thanks!

120552,OPEN,Collapsing a node in a hover placed above the line shouldn't make the hover to close,debug; under-discussion,2021-04-06 12:43:50 +0000 UTC,olivierr91,,"- VS Code Version: 1.55.0

When hovering a variable during debug, for example an object or an array, VS code nicely shows a navigable inline tree in a hover. Problem is, when collapsing node, if the hover appears above the line, the popup moves during the collapse, which makes the cursor to go out of the hover and makes the hover disappear. This should be fixed with a small, maybe configurable, delay where the hover  does not disappear when the cursor is out.
1. In a TypeScript project, during debug, hover an array or object with nested information. Make the pop-up to appear at the top of the line, by scrolling your code up a bit if necessary.
4. The hover moves back to it's collapsed size and the cursor is out of the hover.
5. Try to move the cursor back into the hover.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

column1: 120538,OPEN,Add TerminalOptions.icon API to support tabs in terminal,api; api-proposal; feature-request; integrated-terminal,2021-04-07 16:03:31 +0000 UTC,Tyriar,,https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/120241,,
I currently working on my plugin for Visual Studio solution files (*.sln)
And I was wonder why a merge was not show any diagnostic.
So after a little debug I have found that when I open a solution file via the SCM the `textDocument.languageId` is set to `plaintext` and not to `sln`.
I think the Problem is that the `fsPath` of the document end with `sln.git`  and not with `.sln`.
vscode itself understand this and show the correct language in the language selector (bottom right).
my current workaround for this is (`src\RegisterEvents.ts`)
1. Open a supported file on scm
2. Check the `languageId` of the current visible document
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

120516,OPEN,Support fractional numbers in window.zoomlevel from keyboard zoom actions,feature-request; zoom,2021-04-05 14:53:11 +0000 UTC,mosfetish,,When using ctrl++, ctrl+-, and ctrl+0 to zoom/shrink/reset window zoom, window.zoomlevel in settings.json is updated or completely removed, as in the case of resetting with ctrl+0.
A setting applied in settings.json should not be updated/removed by using simple keyboard actions.

Many users set window.zoomlevel to something like 0.4 to increase the size of the window chrome since there is no other way to do it in Code. But they still need to use the keyboard zoom from time to time.
So here's what happens with window.zoomlevel in settings.json when using the keyboard zoom actions:
What should happen if Code is respecting the user setting is this:

In other words, the user setting of 0.4 should become another step in the keyboard zoom sequence and not be removed. And using ctrl+0 when a user-defined setting is in settings.json should reset the zoom to the user-defined setting, and not remove the setting.
It's pretty frustrating to do temporary zoom-in and have the setting overwritten or deleted.
,, 120515,OPEN,Can open VS Code while it's being updated,bug; install-update; windows,2021-04-06 08:39:53 +0000 UTC,ijtan,,Issue Type: Bug
I often have to restart vscode when things get stuck (not the issue).

I am encountering an issue where after I close and reopen vscode (without waiting a bit), vscode starts normally, and then, after a few seconds (by which I would have started working on the code again), the 'updating vscode window' comes up and forcibly recloses vscode.
This seems to be an issue with the auto-update which occurs when vsc is closed, which I don't mind. Yet I think it should check if VSCode was reopened before forcing it to close.
So in essence I end up:
- re-open vsc immediately to continue working
- start working on the code which I restarted for
- after few seconds, vsc forcibly shut by the update window
- have to reopen vscode once again after the update

column1: 120477,OPEN,Language server from extension is killed without any feedback when opening SCM tab,,2021-04-04 16:06:13 +0000 UTC,Runi-c,,"https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5150427/113488188-b5fad380-9479-11eb-972a-c17fdbad46d3.mp4

5. While explorer tab is open, the extension works. Save the following content to a file named ""test.rkt"":
6. Observe one syntax error appear to confirm langserver and extension are working.
7. Set Magic-racket > Trace: Server setting to Verbose
7. View > Output and watch the ""Racket Language Client"" tab
8. Click the Source Control Tab. The ""Racket Language Client"" tab instantly vanishes, and the error is no longer reported. No language features work until a reload of VSC.

9. Reload VSC while on Source Control Tab, then check ""Racket Language Client"" tab. Observe that the client sends ""Initialize"" immediately followed in few ms by ""Shutdown"", giving no chance for the language server to even start up.

### Unfortunately, search gets **very** annoying of one splits the Editor:

If we switch between the split Editors, it's no longer possible to just press `F3` so repeat the last search command. We have to redefine the Search and Search/Replace setting for each split editor. Therefore it's a nightmare if VSCode is used with three or four split Editors.
### Feature request: Please allow us to use *one* Search and Search/Replace function for all Split Editors

120437,OPEN,How to update a single child node from a list of hundreds of child nodes under a TreeItem parent,,2021-04-05 12:28:57 +0000 UTC,davidkjackson54,,I have an Explorer Treeview and a parent in the tree can have hundreds of child nodes.  Each child node then has right click options to perform specific tasks.
A right click option can change the state of the child node and so I need to refresh that child node in order toe re-establish the current state and refresh the right click options.

Currently, I am having to perform a refresh on the parent node which is then triggerts onDidChangeTreeData  which then in turn triggers getChildren to go  rebuild that entire child structure below the parent. This all works but it is very  inefficient and takes time to go through and rebuild as there can be hundreds of child nodes and each is refreshed by issuing a REST api to another platform.

I can find no documentation on how I can get access to just the specific child node from the array of child nodes that was originally created in getChildren too allow me to update just that single child entry..
Is there the ability to update a single child node ? I have not found any example of suggestions in this area.
Same question for deleting one single child node ?? Without having to rebuild the entire parent structure?
120433,OPEN,"Add context awareness in regards to Windows 10's ""task view""",,2021-04-05 12:25:49 +0000 UTC,DamonStamper,,"Commit: e5a624b788d92b8d34d1392e4c4d9789406efe8f
- List of extensions that you have installed
- Reproducible steps (1... 2... 3...) that cause the issue
2 on the first task view open vscode
4 using windows explorer in the 2nd task view, open a file that will open in vscode
5 notice that you are switched back to task view 1, and the file is opened in addition to any other files that were open in VSCode on taskview 1 resulting in unintentional context switching.

Please note that you are able to open VSCode manually in whatever context you desire and are able to open a file from VSCode. You can also ensure that your context's VSCode window is the last VSCode window that was selected then opening a file through Windows Explorer will send the file to that VSCode instance.
- What you expected to see, versus what you actually saw
Opening a file is not aware of which ""task view"" to use when opening VSCode
- Images, animations, or a link to a video showing the issue occurring
- A code snippet that demonstrates the issue or a link to a code repository the developers can easily pull down to recreate the issue locally
- Note: Because the developers need to copy and paste the code snippet, including a code snippet as a media file (i.e. .gif) is not sufficient.
- Errors from the Dev Tools Console (open from the menu: Help > Toggle Developer Tools)

120431,OPEN,Electron: Enable renderer process reuse,electron-12-update; feature-request; sandbox; workbench-electron,2021-04-10 12:01:23 +0000 UTC,rzhao271,,1. Are the processes killed + restarted during a reload?
2. Are the processes killed + restarted when a user opens a new folder or workspace? I'm currently trying to see if such actions are equivalent to a reload right now, but haven't yet found the code.

3. If yes to 1 and/or 2, can they be set up in a way using IPC such that the main process can send a reset signal during reloads? This way, we can continue using the same child process, and it's just the state of the child process that gets reset.

120420,OPEN,Electron: Consider to leverage `nativeTheme.themeSource` to enforce light or dark mode in window,feature-request; help wanted; titlebar; workbench-os-integration,2021-04-10 07:25:41 +0000 UTC,rinsuki,,Electron has `require(""electron"").nativeTheme.themeSource` API and `BrowserWindow#vibrancy` API that can overrides system appearance per app/window, so I injected `require(""electron"").nativeTheme.themeSource = ""dark""` to `Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/main.js` (yeah, its unsupported, i know) and looks pretty great.
However, I think code injection is not supported, possibly corrupting the installed VS Code, and disabling it with every VS Code update.
so I'll suggest new settings that overrides macOS appearance based on VSCode theme.
**Note:** I think this new settings may conflicts with `window.autoDetectColorScheme` and `window.autoDetectHighContrast`.",,

Honestly, I wouldn't mind the crashes for terminal but this causes my **Remote SSH disconnects from the server and I have to reload all windows one by one.** Even local VSCode crashes, all other open windows disconnects if they are connected to a SSH Server.

120377,OPEN,VS Code rollback does not preserve update mode setting,needs more info,2021-04-07 02:59:19 +0000 UTC,olderor,,As the recent update (1.55.0) broke some functionality for me, I'm trying to rollback to 1.54.3. However, the VS Code keeps updating to the latest 1.55.0 even though the updates setting is set to none.
1. Install VS Code 1.54.3, get an update to 1.55.0, and install it.
2. Close VS Code 1.55.0, install an older version (1.54.3 in my case https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_54).
3. Open VS Code 1.54.3, go to User Settings, search for 'update'.
4. Set update mode to none instead of the default (disables all updates as per description).
6. Done. Observe the VS Code is updated from 1.54.3 to 1.55.0, a release notes page appears even though the update mode is set to none.
7. Go to user settings, observe the update mode is set to none, but VS Code was still updated. You can also repeat steps 2-5 and observe the same.
After setting update mode to none and restarting VS Code, the app should prevent itself from installing any updates and keep the version that was used in the previous launch.",,

column1: 120369,OPEN,Allow extensions to contribute terminal profiles,api; api-proposal; feature-request; integrated-terminal; integrated-terminal-profiles,2021-04-07 16:06:07 +0000 UTC,davidanthoff,,"
that reads `New Julia REPL`, and then calls a function in our extension that executes all the necessary steps to start a new Julia REPL in a terminal window.

Ideally that would also help with a ""restart"" scenario. Right now, if a user starts a new Julia REPL, has that open and then restarts VS Code, VS code starts a new shell that wasn't open in the previous instance. With this feature idea here, I could imagine that VS code at shutdown ""remembers"" which terminal profile was used to create which terminal instance, and then at restart uses the correct terminal profile to recreate the same terminal that was open in the previous instance.",,
120368,OPEN,Terminal API: Allow initial text to be shown,api; api-proposal; feature-request; integrated-terminal,2021-04-07 16:02:27 +0000 UTC,Tyriar,,"Proposal: `TerminalOptions.initialText: string`

Example use case: GitLens running a git command and when it fails, create a new terminal which includes the error message in the header and the failed command ready to be run manually. This is generally useful for other applications (eg. welcome to the blah debug terminal, this is how it works, ...)

120328,OPEN,Use resolveAsync in terminal Variable Resolver,debt; important; perf-startup,2021-04-06 12:37:52 +0000 UTC,alexr00,,With https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/108804 we are trying to remove process.env from the configuration resolver service. The new way to get the environment is async and requires that the all the configuration resolver methods be async. I have started the adoption of the new async methods in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/120326, but there's one use in terminal that looks like it will require more work:
Option 1: Convert that use of `resolve` to use `resolveAsync`.
Option 2: I provide a new `resolveWithEnv` method on the configuration resolver service that is sync, but requires you to pass in your own `IProcessEnvironment`.
Which option makes the most sense here?",,

column1: 120307,OPEN,Fuzzy matching of file paths between client and server during remote debug session?,debug; under-discussion,2021-04-01 21:58:37 +0000 UTC,markus-breyer,,"I am working on a debug adapter implementation in conjunction with VSCode. We are using TCP/IP transport to connect to a remote cloud server which runs the actual debugged process, and all is working quite well. I am having an issue mapping source files between the remote process and the local VSCode project, since source is compiled in the cloud and file names do not match the local VSCode client 100%. For example, a file with the local path `C:\Users\Zorro\Documents\Projects\MyProject18\Content\Script\MyProject18_Logic.verse` might end up with the remote path `c:\build\Game\Plugins\GameFeatures\dea629ee-42b0-d957-1e67-7ea94c6ff0e5\Content\Script\myproject18_logic.verse`. When the user sets a breakpoint, we use a fuzzy path comparison in the debug target to match one to the other which works great. However, when we send a stack frame back to the client, VSCode does not find the path and reports an error message: `Unable to open 'myproject18_logic.verse': Unable to read file 'c:\build\Game\Plugins\GameFeatures\dea629ee-42b0-d957-1e67-7ea94c6ff0e5\Content\Script\myproject18_logic.verse' (Error: Unable to resolve non-existing file 'c:\build\Game\Plugins\GameFeatures\dea629ee-42b0-d957-1e67-7ea94c6ff0e5\Content\Script\myproject18_logic.verse').`. I understand the DAP has a ""source reference"" mechanism that allows the client to refer to source files by ID and retrieve them from the debugged process. We'd like to avoid having to store all source code on the debug target though, and also prefer the user to work directly with their local source files, so when they click up the call stack they get referred to code locations in their local project, not to unrelated source content transferred from the debugged target.

Is there a way to have VSCode fuzzy match the file paths of debugged code locations between target and client workspace? Or better, a mechanism that would allow the debug target to retrieve all existing file paths in the client's workspace (like a reverse LoadedSources request) so the fuzzy mapping can be performed in the debug adapter?
Any help and/or ideas would be appreciated!",,
120304,OPEN,VSC v1.55.0 on macos loses keyboard shortcuts,needs more info,2021-04-11 01:13:12 +0000 UTC,robayris,,"

Today I updated to v1.55.0 of VSC on my mac (macos Big Sur 11.2.3).  At startup all the regular copy'n'paste, end-of-line, start-of-line keyboard shortcuts work, but once I then build and run one of my apps (Garmin Connect IQ app using the Monkey C extension v0.1.9 - which hasn't been updated for months) all those editing keyboard shortcuts, particularly copy'n'paste, end-of-line (command+right), start-of-line (command+left) stop working and I have to completely restart VSC to get them back (the shortcuts still work on other mac apps, just not in VSC).  Also, after doing this a number of times, VSC appears to become unstable and I lose connection to my Git repository, whereupon, I have to completely reboot my mac.  something is amiss.

120276,OPEN,Use Shadow DOM for notebook outputs?,notebook-output; under-discussion,2021-04-02 22:29:16 +0000 UTC,mjbvz,,#120137 uses Shadow DOM to isolate rendered markdown cells in notebooks.I propose we also adopt Shadow DOM for the output renderers.

The main benefit is isolation: Shadow DOMs should prevent css from one output rendered leaking over into another output renderer. It should also help prevent css from an output renderer leaking into the rest of the back layer webview. This isolation would not be perfect, but I think using a Shadow DOM would steer output renderers in the correct direction

**This would be a breaking change for the output renderer API**. Specifically, it would break renderers that insert global styles/scripts into the back layer webview. Code [like this](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-github-issue-notebooks/blob/bcb13e010c73d99682aaa0e4348fca79f27bc0b2/src/renderer/index.tsx#L11) from the GitHub issue notebook would no longer work (although the workaround is pretty simple: just insert the link tag into the Shadow DOM instead)

120260,OPEN,Be smarter about when we render notebook output in monaco editors,feature-request; notebook; notebook-output,2021-03-31 20:07:40 +0000 UTC,connor4312,,"Peng and I were talking about https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/120219 by @firelizzard18.

Currently, in notebooks we special case the `application/json` mimetype to be rendered with syntax highlighting in an editor. In the issue, Ethan requested a way to render code in the same way within the renderer, but this is hard for a number of reasons. Instead, it would be nice if there was a way to render other languages in the same way we special-case application/json.
Currently, language contributions already list their mimetypes
so instead of special casing JSON, we could have generic logic that can render mimetypes for any installed language in an editor.
Another way would be an optional property on the cell output...
-  constructor(mime: string, value: unknown, metadata?: Record<string, any>);
+  constructor(mime: string, value: unknown, metadata?: Record<string, any>, languageId?: string);
but I think this is overkill where the mime type mapping could 'just work'.

120176,OPEN,Setting sync: Sign in dialogs not accessibility friendly,accessibility; bug; settings-sync,2021-04-06 09:40:07 +0000 UTC,isidorn,,"From https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/120012 by @neurrone

This dialog is very unnacessible. Problems:
* Once the dialog is created the ""Please sign in to synchronize"" part is not being read out by screen reader. I recommend to use a placeholder since that would nicely be read.

* It is hard for the user to figure out there are checkboxes below. Aria label of the input box should contain this information

* Checkbox list items do not have `aria-checked` set on them. For example on how to do this, checkout [breakpoints](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/contrib/debug/browser/breakpointsView.ts#L848)

120173,OPEN,Workspace trust extension API,api; api-finalization; workspace-trust,2021-04-06 07:50:12 +0000 UTC,lszomoru,,## Extension API

As described above, the first step to using the API is adding the static declarations to your `package.json`. The easiest method of onboarding would be to use the *onStart* value for the `required` property. Once again, this is the default behavior even if you do nothing, but it's a great signal to the user that you have made a deliberate choice. In this case, your extension does not need to do anything else. It will simply not be activated until trust is given and your extension can know that it is executing with the consent of the user. However, if your extension only requires trust for part of its functionality, this is likely not the best option.
For extensions that wish to gate their features on Workspace Trust, they should use the *onDemand* value for the `required` property, and we provide the following API:
* The workspace is untrusted, and it will have limited functionality.
* The workspace is trusted, and all functionality will be available.
* The initial state of the workspace.
* If trust will be required, users will be prompted to make a choice.
* The event data that is fired when the trust state of the workspace changes
* New trust state of the workspace
* The object describing the properties of the workspace trust request
* When true, a modal dialog will be used to request workspace trust.
* When false, a badge will be displayed on the Setting activity bar item
* The trust state of the current workspace
* Prompt the user to chose whether to trust the current workspace
* @param options Optional object describing the properties of the
* Event that fires when the trust state of the current workspace changes

The crux of the API surface is at the bottom. We provide a property to get the current Workspace Trust state, an asynchronous method to request Workspace Trust to the user, and finally an event for listening to Workspace Trust state changes.

You will notice that the method to require Workspace Trust `requireWorkspaceTrust(options?: WorkspaceTrustRequestOptions)` takes an optional argument with a `modal` property. This `modal` value describes how the request should be surfaced to the user. It should be set to:

- **true** - when the requirement is in response to an explicit user action. For example, suppose you have a command that requires Workspace Trust to run. When the user explicitly runs this command, you should require workspace trust with this value set to *true* and await the result. This will trigger a prompt to the user with a modal dialog and should be used for explicit actions only.

- **false** - when the requirement is for a background feature of your extension. For example, suppose you want to use the workspace version of a node module to provide errors. In this case, it is best to call the function with this value set to *false* and await the result. This will trigger a UX indication that Workspace Trust is being requested but will not interrupt the user.
Extension authors will be able to declare in the extension manifest the workspace trust requirements for the extension:
For the `required` property, the following values are accepted:
- **false** - The extension does not require workspace trust to perform any functionality.
- **'onDemand'** - The extension functions partially without workspace trust. Some features will be disabled until workspace trust is granted. The extension can use API to gate features.
- **'onStart'** - The extension cannot function without workspace trust. It will remain disabled until workspace trust is given.

For the `description` property, a description of why trust is needed may be provided to help the user understand what features will be disabled or what they should review before granting or denying workspace trust.

For the `safeSettings` property, a list of settings may be provided that the extension can safely read from the workspace even when the workspace is not trusted. More detail is provide on this topic below. Note that this value is relevant only when the `required` property is set to `false` or `'onDemand'` as the extension will be disabled in untrusted workspaces for `'onStart'`.",,

120164,OPEN,Debugging does not use automation shell,,2021-03-30 11:07:50 +0000 UTC,bbennetts,,"
1. launch a debugging session with cppdbg or vadimcn.vscode-lldb using a bash terminal
2. Note that the terminal launched is interactive (bash options are ""himBH"")

The documentation (https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/supporting/troubleshoot-terminal-launch) states that ""terminal.integrated.automationShell.{platform} - Shell path for automation-related terminal usage like tasks and debug."" however debugging as far as I can tell is invoking the non-automation shell.  This is problematic because to be able to differentiate between an automation process (build/debug) and an interactive process (terminal launched by user) is important/useful.
Already raised a ticket versus [vscode-cpptools](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-cpptools/issues/7192), but the opinion is that this is a vscode issue.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

120120,OPEN,Adopt `@link` in vscode.d.ts,debt,2021-03-29 18:35:46 +0000 UTC,mjbvz,,Tracks adopting JSDoc `@link` tags in `vscode.d.ts`. Unlike our existing link scheme, these links should work properly in hovers and suggest widgets. However they do require TS 4.3+
2. **May**: Pick up TS 4.3. Start updating `vscode.d.ts` to use `@link` tags.
3. **May**: Ensure the website's doc generator can parse `@link` tags.

4. **May Release**: Users targeting the latest VS Code version get the `vscode.d.ts` that uses `@link`. However users targeting older versions of VS Code will get the `d.ts` that uses our custom link scheme
5. **Post May**: All new llinks added to `vscode.d.ts` should use `@link`
6. **Future?**: Remove custom link support? This would break `#link` in old `vscode.d.ts` versions
We can also try this out in `vscode.proposed.d.ts`, since we don't have to worry about supporting older versions of that file",,

column1: 120077,OPEN,Terminal environmentVariableCollection should respect clearing entries,integrated-terminal; integration-test-failure,2021-03-29 07:01:25 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,"https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/runs/2216043935?check_suite_focus=true#step:15:431

Error: Timeout of 60000ms exceeded. For async tests and hooks, ensure ""done()"" is called; if returning a Promise, ensure it resolves. (D:\a\vscode\vscode\extensions\vscode-api-tests\out\singlefolder-tests\terminal.test.js)
Create a notion of a prefix-based suggestion grouping. Here's one possibility of how this can be configured:
Here's an example of the behaviour I'm thinking of, given the above settings configuration:

For each of the four above scenarios, the current behaviour upon triggering suggestions will include showing every aria-___ option that exists. The behaviour that I'm proposing would be that for the first three scenarios, triggering suggestions will include a single ""group"" instead of all aria-___ options. The group would have text along the lines of ""`aria ... (type ""aria"" to see more)`"", and then for the fourth scenario where the configured prefix has been fully typed out, the group will show all 48 of its contents.
The `restMatches` optional parameter takes a regular expression string, and is used to filter options which should be part of the group.
It may also be useful to have a `restNotMatches` parameter.

It would also probably be useful to be able to configure which types of [completion item kinds](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/editor/common/modes.ts#L445) should or shouldn't be in the group (Ex. text suggestions probably shouldn't be included in groups).
I haven't thought of how nesting should be handled, but I think whatever's the least surprising is best (if there is one option that is the least surprising).
2. Type out any full suggestion and press enter
3. Expect newline, but instead it accepts the suggestion you have already fully typed.

At first, I thought this issue was isolated to a single language, as I noticed it malfunctioning on my first day learning Go. However, I then tested with TypeScript and Python and experienced the same bug. Maybe it's just on my end? Appreciate the help!

column1: 120063,OPEN,Better names & types for OutputItems like 'application/x.notebook.error-traceback',api; feature-request; notebook,2021-03-29 06:51:48 +0000 UTC,DonJayamanne,,"{
When working on a new extension, i need to go into the Jupyter extension for VS Code to see what' supported.
Similarly whats the structure of the data passed into the following output items?:
Would it be better to have separate output items, e.g. `NotebookCellErrorOutputItem`, `NotebookCellStreamOutputItem`
constructur(value: string, error: {message?: string; name: string; stack?: string})
Finally, not sure why properties are named `ename/evalue/traceback`.

These names seem too tighly coupled with the Jupyter protocol. I'm ok with this, however when creating a kernel for non-jupyter or other, these don't seem right and doesn't feel like a good set of names in for the error object nodejs world.
FYI - Please consider this feedback from someone new to Notebooks (missing types/information/docs), or someone working on non-Jupyter notebooks (ename, evalue, etc seem like alient terms).

column1: 120003,OPEN,Predefined variable for word under cursor,feature-request; keybindings,2021-04-01 15:17:30 +0000 UTC,andycraig,,"```
If the cursor was not within a word, it could take the value of a zero-length string.

A use case for this is to define commands for quickly summarising variables. E.g., using the following we could quickly get the length of the variable under the cursor in a Python file, when using running a Python REPL in the terminal:
Other uses for this in Python would be `${wordUnderCursor}.columns` and `${wordUnderCursor}.head()` for summarising data frames.

We implement something like this in an [R extension for VS Code](https://github.com/Ikuyadeu/vscode-R#creating-keybindings-for-r-commands). `$$` is substituted with the selection, or with the word under the cursor if there's no selection, and it's quite useful. It would be nice to have something like this available for all languages that use REPLs.
Thank you for making such a nice editor!",,

119962,OPEN,Allow progress notification to switch back to indefinite mode,api; feature-request; workbench-notifications,2021-03-26 15:59:22 +0000 UTC,nahk-ivanov,,    { location: vscode.ProgressLocation.Notification },
progress.report({ message: ""Still reports progress here, but we need indefinite"" });

The scenario is rather simple – we download the file (have progress) and then extract it (do not have progress, depending on the archive format). I guess I could create new notification window, but that would just unnecessarily complicate the code. Ideally, I’d just run both actions under the same long running task and just flip the progress back to indefinite for some of the steps.

After quick conversation with @bpasero , the current API is set in stone and we can't give a new meaning to `undefined` increment. One way could be to just add new method to `Progress<>`, but it seems like not all progress locations support progress bar, so it will not make much sense for anything other than `ProgressLocation.Notification`. If we want to shove it in the generic of the `Progress<>`, then maybe just allow `{ increment: 'indefinite' }` and check for it being a string?",,

119949,OPEN,Define push model for notebook kernels,api; feature-request; notebook; notebook-kernel; under-discussion,2021-04-07 14:42:24 +0000 UTC,jrieken,,Today, notebook kernels are operating on a pull model, e.g there is a kernel provider that returns kernels. With that approach there is an API violation since kernels aren't data-only objects and the overall the pull model causes headaches because we don't really know when to pull for kernels. Instead, kernels should use a push model, e.g extensions create kernels as managed objects and are responsible for their lifecycle.

This means there will be a `createNotebookKernel`-function which returns a kernel instance. The kernel will have properties and functions that allow to drive the VS Code UI for a kernel (this is similar to `createStatusBarItem` or `createSourceControl`). This leads to the question what a kernel is? As far as VS Code is concerned kernels enable the execute commands, show in the status bar, and drive the kernel picker. There is no further mapping of ""actual"" kernels, the API is there to drive the UI and initiate execution.
This leads to an API like this (rough sketches!)
export function createNotebookKernel(id: string, label: string, selector: NotebookSelector, executeHandler: (notebook: NotebookDocument, cells: NotebookCell[]) => void): NotebookKernel;
// select notebook of a type and/or by file-pattern
// invoked when Run, Run All, Run Selections is triggered,
// command is invoked with [kernel, cells] as arguments
// kernels can establish IPC channels to (visible) notebook editors
Details are to be defined but gist of it should be clear. Consequences that are not so obvious are the following:

* when and iff kernels appear depends entirely on extensions and we are at the mercy of extensions getting this right, e.g be swift and painless in creating kernels (good defaults, no prompts etc). This is not novel and seems to work well enough for similar APIs, like SCM or comments.

* Not strictly a consequence of this but kernels should become ""private"" objects, e.g only the extension that creates a kernel knows about it and no public object can reference a kernel. That means `NotebookCommunication#kernel` and `onDidChangeActiveNotebookKernel` should go away. Already today that's fishy because any extension can interact with any kernel, like interrupting it or executing arbitrary cells.

119917,OPEN,Support Hovers and IntelliSense in search editor,feature-request,2021-03-25 23:41:22 +0000 UTC,devuxer,,"I just started experimenting with search editors again after a few false starts where I just wasn't seeing the value in the feature yet. This time, I got far enough to actually think it has real promise, but I was surprised by how limited the editor was compared with an actual code editor (in my case, the JS/TS editor).

The first example I came across is not being able to hover a TypeScript type to see its definition. I soon also noticed the lack of intellisense and red error squiggles (is there an official name for these?). I'm sure there are other examples.

These deficiencies really limit the usefulness of the search editor. The particular use case that led me to submit this request was that I was trying to verify the return type of a bunch functions throughout my codebase. Not being able to just interrogate the type right in the search editor added a lot of clicks and made the process a lot more tedious than it could have been.
(I would also add that having to learn about and install ""Search Editor: Apply Changes"" is not ideal, but I think I saw that a more integrated, discoverable solution is in the works.)
So, my feature request is to make the search editor behave like a regular code editor, to the extent possible.",,

119899,OPEN,Kernel and renderer compatibility constraints,notebook,2021-04-08 22:22:35 +0000 UTC,connor4312,,"In the initial prototype of renderers, we said that kernels would expose an interface in their preloads, and if a renderer loads in and sees that the expected interface is missing, it would be responsible for showing appropriate help to the user. However, this is not a polished experience for a variety of reasons.

In an ideal world both kernel-providing extensions and renderers statically define their compatibility ""tags"", but Jupyter kernels can be discovered and changed dynamically, so this is not possible. My plan is that:
- Kernels can expose well-known ""tags"" at runtime in VS Code (or aznb)
- Renderers statically define required or optional tags in their package.json.

This means that when we render an output, we can determine what and whether any installed renderers are compatible. With a marketplace integration that would let us search by tags, we also can suggest renderers that could be useful for the output. This is particularly important if the execution produces a mime type for which there is no existing renderer.

Currently kernels have a list of `preload` URIs, but these preloads also define the API(s) that the kernel provides. I suggest introducing a new `NotebookKernelPreload` interface that would be used instead:
Then in package.jsons, renders could define a list of `dependencies` or `optionalDependencies`.

Dependencies is a ""one of"" list -- the renderer will be considered compatible if at least one of the requested dependencies is provided by the kernel. `optionalDependencies` can be used to hint at compatibility or kernels that can allow for better integration, but aren't required. When picking a renderer to use for some new output, VS Code will prefer renderers that have an available kernel in their dependencies over those which do not.
**To be discussed:** Do we need to 'pattern match' dependencies, e.g. could I optionally depend on any ""jupyter dap"" kernel with `jupyter/*/dap` versus specifically `jupyter/python/dap`.
**Updated from discussion:** To choose a renderer for an output, VS Code will assume 'richer-is-better' and prefer:
- For each mime type in the output, choose:
1. return renderer with a hard dependency on an available kernel, otherwise
2. return renderer with an optional dependency on an available kernel, otherwise
3. return any other renderer for this mimetype.
- If no suitable renderer is found, show a 'fallback' for the first mime type.  VS Code will suggest searching in the marketplace for an output renderer, and provide a button to do so.

When opening a new notebook with existing output, VS Code will choose the best available renderer assuming that whatever kernel dependency it needs will eventually be available. Therefore, renderers must be able to deal with a kernel loading in after the first render.
If a cell is executed and its output renderer is no longer compatible with the current kernel, the selection algorithm runs again.

119829,OPEN,Dropdown menus disappear when hovering in 4K screen,,2021-03-25 13:59:35 +0000 UTC,Hadakajime,,"

When running vscode in a 4K multi-monitor setup, the dropdown menus will flicker random option highlighting in the root dropdown, when you hover over sub-menu options. Then the whole menu will randomly close as you keep moving your mouse to cause the flickering. So to select any sub-menu option, you have to be quick and click on it regardless of the currently highlighted option, before the whole thing closes by itself.
This issue was introduced only in the last 2 months or so, I think.

119786,OPEN,Editor hover: markdown links should use their own custom scheme,debt; editor-hover; sandbox,2021-03-25 08:06:37 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,Steps to Reproduce:
3. comment out the line that reads `Image preview is currently not supported`
5. open a markdown document with a reference to a PNG in the workspace
=> 🐛 it looks like the resulting image tag uses `file` protocol and not `vscode-file` protocol:
We need to make sure to use the `FileAccess` utility to properly convert to a URL that the browser can handle.

Slightly related: @deepak1556 expressed some interest that the generated HTML from markdown uses a custom scheme so that we can distinguish markdown content from our core content. I had to push https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/a34297a60858cf43f4bc92aae48b72e3ea37754a now as a workaround.

,,
119785,OPEN,Pause animated gifs in extension readmes,feature-request,2021-03-30 06:04:36 +0000 UTC,WilcoFiers,,Steps to Reproduce:
2. Search for comment-autocomplete (or any number of other extensions with animated gifs)
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported direct to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

It is fairly common place for extensions to include animated gifs in their readme. These then show up on the marketplace page on visualstudio.com, as well as in VSCode itself. Animated gifs can be fairly distracting for people with certain cognitive disabilities such as autism. For quite a few people, animations are so distracting, it is essentially impossible for them to read the text. This is captured in the [pause, stop, hide](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/pause-stop-hide.html) requirement of Web Content Accessibility Guidelines.

One way this could be addressed is for VSC to wrap each animated gif in a little widget that adds a small pause / play toggle button in the bottom right (or left for RTL languages). There are some tools to do this out there, such as [freezeframe.js](https://ctrl-freaks.github.io/freezeframe.js/) The best solution would be only to animate when the user hovers / activates the image. Make sure to make the mechanism to start/pause keyboard accessible.",,

119707,OPEN,"Should ""openInBackground"" for Getting Started work when extension isn't installed from vsix?",bug; getting-started,2021-03-30 18:48:54 +0000 UTC,bamurtaugh,,"Testing #119543

The primary walkthrough opens successfully for me with `""workbench.welcomePage.experimental.extensionContributions"": ""open""`. For instance, when I have the Getting Started editor already open and `settings.json` as the focused tab:
I'm also able to open it to the side with the Getting Started page already open, `settings.json` in focus, and `""workbench.welcomePage.experimental.extensionContributions"": ""openToSide""` set:

However, when I have `""workbench.welcomePage.experimental.extensionContributions"": ""openInBackground""` set, when I install https://github.com/JacksonKearl/md-to-html/ from the Extensions viewlet, the walkthrough opens up and takes the primary view. I thought it would've opened a tab but that tab wouldn't have taken over the focus.
I tried uninstalling the extension, reloading the window, and installing from a vsix instead, and now getting started loaded in the background:

119631,OPEN,Terminal `onLineData` is inserting extra white space characters into lines that get broken,bug; integrated-terminal; tasks,2021-03-26 12:59:50 +0000 UTC,alexr00,,"To repro:
1. Start the VS Code build task.
4. Cause an error in the build task in a file where the file name wraps to a new terminal line.
5. Observe that when the breakpoint is hit, wrapped lines have extra spaces, often in the middle of file names which is particularly bad for the terminal tasks system.
Discussed with @Tyriar, and it seems that setting `""terminal.integrated.localEchoLatencyThreshold"": -1` fixes the issue.",,
