column1: 117879,OPEN,"Disabling ""Copy With Syntax Highlighting"" still keeps some garbage in clipboard",,2021-03-04 01:05:44 +0000 UTC,jihu,,"Commit: 622cb03f7e070a9670c94bae1a45d78d7181fbd4

Disabling the setting ""_Copy With Syntax Highlighting_"" (ie setting ""**editor.copyWithSyntaxHighlighting**"": **false**) does not work properly. I expect that having disabled this setting, anything I copy (using regular **Ctrl+C**) from the editor should be in pure plain text format. But my tests show that not to be the case. I had problems pasting the text in an online word document, edited in the Chrome browser. The text gets pasted with a bold format. If I paste it into notepad, then copying that text, then the text is clean when pasted into word.

Using the windows program **ClipView**, that shows technical details about the current clipboard content, I was able to identify the problem. When copying text in Visual Studio Code, even with ""editor.copyWithSyntaxHighlighting"": false, it adds a clipboard format called ""**Chromium Web Custom MIME Data Format**"". If I copy text from notepad this ""Chromium Web Custom MIME Data Format"" is not included. And some programs, like the Word web editor in Chrome it seems, sees this format and decides ""this text should have a bold format!"".
1. Open Visual Studio Code with all extensions disabled
2. Write some text in some plain text format, select the text, and copy it using Ctrl+C
3. Inspect the clipboard content using ClipView (or some similar program)
* Only regular plain text clipboard formats should be seen
* A clipboard format called ""Chromium Web Custom MIME Data Format"" is included

I see this as a bug. With the setting ""editor.copyWithSyntaxHighlighting"": false, any copied text should be pure plain text in the clipboard, and nothing else. So the clipboard format called ""Chromium Web Custom MIME Data Format"" should be removed.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes",,

117873,OPEN,Editor model world should offer some amenities to protect against data loss / file corruption,custom-editors; debt; important; notebook; workbench-editors,2021-04-09 14:03:11 +0000 UTC,jrieken,,"Normal file editors, custom editors, and notebooks all implement editors for something on a file system. All implement the relatively rigid structure of editor inputs and editor models. However, they get little to nothing in return for implementing this, there is no service-like infrastructure that makes my live simpler, e.g

* [x] there is logic for sequentialising saves inside [`TextFileEditorModel`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/509cd79dbd636b198c1e21ebe3059256262ebe4d/src/vs/workbench/services/textfile/common/textFileEditorModel.ts#L675) and roughly the same code exists (was copied) for [notebook editors](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/02b2629dd1c15c40836103ecf8d42a385abf1528/src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/common/notebookEditorModel.ts#L283). Custom editors tackle the same problem, but uses [different](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/f3f4eebecbd47df5012d773fcfcadc4e65fbe79b/src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadCustomEditors.ts#L586) code. So, instead of everyone re-inventing the wheel the ""framework"", which interfaces I must implement, should take care of this for me.

* [x] there is duplicated logic for when a file is being deleted, e.g text file editors have [`inOrphanMode`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/509cd79dbd636b198c1e21ebe3059256262ebe4d/src/vs/workbench/services/textfile/common/textFileEditorModel.ts#L124-L124) and custom editors have [`_inOrphaned`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/f3f4eebecbd47df5012d773fcfcadc4e65fbe79b/src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadCustomEditors.ts#L407-L407). There is a utility method [`decorateFileEditorLabel`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/9f7d229461a3af85a6977b842cd0445ad9396f19/src/vs/workbench/contrib/files/common/editors/fileEditorInput.ts#L391-L391) to decorate the editor label to indicate orphaned editors but this should move into a common super type. Notebooks didn't copy this yet. Again, I should be able to express to the framework that I am some kind of file editor and then deletion should be taken care of

* [x] the logic for general file watching is duplicated, e.g when a file on disk changes we reload it unless the file is dirty ([text files](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/277c60fc0a20ee56c6ed83041434a1f136a6cb99/src/vs/workbench/services/textfile/common/textFileEditorModelManager.ts#L111-L111), [notebooks](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/65e283212409e65a7c90b59831d671b7dd2ded9b/src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/common/notebookEditorModel.ts#L81-L81)). The framework should do that automatically because I already tell it how to load and whether my model is dirty or not.

* [ ] there is a [`TextFileEditorTracker`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/277c60fc0a20ee56c6ed83041434a1f136a6cb99/src/vs/workbench/contrib/files/browser/editors/textFileEditorTracker.ts#L18-L18) that takes care of opening dirty models and reloading them when the window gains focus but this code is only used for text file models. Notebooks has [`NotebookFileTracker`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/c13b21f7f8cc7d976fda541a03752f31426b4fe6/src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/browser/notebook.contribution.ts#L713-L713) for that

* [x] there is a complex dirty write prevention code in file service [validateWriteFile](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/cda3b7e157fe0cbd0dfad66a30aa3cbd2ddd1e47/src/vs/platform/files/common/fileService.ts#L394-L414) . A simple version was implemented in notebook but it has ""false negative"" bugs as remote/live-share cases are not covered. Custom editor doesn't handle this yet it seems. Related: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/117715

* [x] text file models [register listeners](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/1a6f64ef1ded53eef9df0d9f3410a9f8f5914f52/src/vs/workbench/services/textfile/electron-browser/nativeTextFileService.ts#L75-L77) to gracefully finish any pending saves on shutdown, which notebooks and custom editors either do not do or currently fail to do with a high risk of data loss

I don't think this list is complete but that's my learning from the little exposure I have gotten via the notebook world. The current approach just seems wasteful: we duplicate code, we duplicate bugs, we duplicate work. ",,
118973,OPEN,Symlinked home path causes aliasing files to be considered different,integrated-terminal; integrated-terminal-links,2021-03-30 21:06:43 +0000 UTC,upsj,,"
I am working on an HPC system where /home is symlinked to another path /some/other/path, which seems to cause some issues:

Having opened /home/some/user/path as a folder, VSCode seems to inconsistently follow the symlink, as the reported absolute path for files is /home/some/user/path, but when I Ctrl+click a relative path in the terminal (where the `pwd` output prints the /home path), the corresponding file in /some/other/path gets opened, which causes issues, since I now have the same file open under two different paths, and the two don't get synchronized.

I am not 100% sure whether I should report this issue on VSCode directly or here, since it seems to be related to file handling in general. An obvious workaround is to use the non-symlinked path to open the folder in VSCode, but this still points to a more fundamental issue.
Let me know if you need any additional information to reproduce this issue.

117819,OPEN,Non-English characters in folder name results in [Error no 2] in Python execution,,2021-02-28 12:07:21 +0000 UTC,tolga-balci,,"

117728,OPEN,Feedback on folding UX for notebook,feature-request; notebook; notebook-folding,2021-02-26 03:53:16 +0000 UTC,mjbvz,,For the example notebook:
I find that I always have trouble understanding how folding works. Here are a few notes on what confused me:
- The fold indicators on all the cells have the same indentation.

To me, it look like all the cells are at the same level, but really folding `verification` folds the `verifiable ...` and `unreleased ...` cells too. Is there some way we could express the hierarchy better?
- There is no preview of what will be folded.
For code, the indent guides sort of offer a preview of the range that will be folded. When you hover over a fold indicator,  could we preview the range of cells that will be folded?
- It is easy to miss that a cell has been folded
In code, we have both line numbers and the folding highlighting that makes folded regions more obvious

,, 117703,OPEN,Git: Rename fails due to malformed file paths on Windows,,2021-02-25 21:20:38 +0000 UTC,Marcono1234,,Issue Type: Bug

The ""Git: Rename"" command added by #97486 apparently performs some file path resolving which can mess up the result file paths, either adding an additional drive letter prefix in front, or adding parent directory references (`\..`) before the drive letter.
In my case I have a `C:` drive containing the Windows and program installations, and a `D:` drive.
1. Open a folder on the `D:` drive in VSCode, e.g. `D:\somefolder\`
2. Create a file in that folder (either from VSCode or Windows Explorer)
3. Create a Git repository (either from VSCode or the command line)
ℹ️ Here it already uses an invalid path in the edit text field: `C:\d:\somefolder\test.txt` (note the leading `C:\`)
5. Replace the suggested file name with the correct `D:\somefolder\new_test.txt` and perform the rename
:x: It fails, the Git log shows:
fatal: Invalid path 'C:/d:': No such file or directory
When I instead create the folder `C:\Users\Someone\Downloads\test` and then repeat the steps, I get this error:
2. open vsc, click on clone repository from welcome screen. says git not installed when it has been installed and is at /user/bin/git

,, 117700,OPEN,Task cwd not correct in multi-root workspace,bug; tasks,2021-03-15 10:12:18 +0000 UTC,hhanesand,,Issue Type: Bug
I've set up a task that builds the current pacakge the user has open in a multi-root workspace. I'm trying to set the task cwd, but it doesn't get the correct value.
When I run the command, I get the following:
> Executing task in folder different-pacakge-name: ~/Developer/repo-name/packages/correct-package-name/../../scripts/run-rush-command.sh -c build <

As we can see in the `command` definition, I'm specifying `${fileWorkspaceFolder}`, which is correctly aliased to ` ~/Developer/repo-name/packages/correct-package-name`, but the task is run in an incorrect folder `different-pacakge-name`.

This causes the $tsc matcher to generate the wrong path, which mean's we're unable to click on the issue to open the file with the issue. `$tsc` thinks the file path is `~/Developer/repo-name/packages/different-pacakge-name/file-path.ts`.
`different-pacakge-name` is coincidentally the alphabetically first root in the multi-root workspace. The same `different-pacakge-name` is used no matter what file I run the task from.
Have I messed something up here?

117644,OPEN,Sluggish scrolling in notebook windows,freeze-slow-crash-leak; needs more info; notebook,2021-03-27 11:52:47 +0000 UTC,DavidKutu,,@oscarrutt commented on [Mon Feb 22 2021](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/issues/4904)

Scrolling in Jupyter notebook windows is sluggish, laggy, and jumpy. It's not horrible but it is bad enough to cause stress, aggravation, and fatigue. Scrolling is nowhere as nice as in other applications when you get that ""massless"" feeling. JupyterLab in Firefox is an example of a Jupyter notebook that runs in a cross-platform environment that scrolls nearly perfectly. The problem appears when scrolling with either two-finger drag on the trackpad or click-dragging the thumb bar in the elevator region.
My computer runs macOS 10.11.6. This is an older version of the OS but it should have no effect on scrolling since all other apps scroll well.
I'm using Jupyter in VSCode Insiders to write Julia. I don't know if the problem extends to non-Julia notebooks.
+1 I've noticed this as well since I started using insiders + native notebooks. (both python and R)
Thanks for letting us know @oscarrutt. I checked on a windows 10 laptop and couldn't feel a difference. I'll make sure to have someone test it with a mac.
@oscarrutt and @jaymegordo, does this only happen with native notebooks? Does it happen say, on a regular python file in vs code?

@DavidKutu I remember really noticing jittery/slow scrolling when I switched from ""old notebooks"" to native notebooks a few moths ago. In a standard large python file I can scroll top-bottom in a fraction of a second, but in a NN there's definitely a bit more resistence. I assume this is probably just related to rendering all the extra assets (tables/charts etc). I _think_ the NN scrolling has improved since I first started using it, but I cant actually compare to the old notebooks right now because they don't even work in my stable vscode (I think its something related to ""experimental"" settings, haven't had time or need to make it work). Its not horrible, just makes me a bit more hesitant to want to scroll around quickly.

So in summary, NN scrolling is definitely slower than a regular python file, but could just be the extra stuff to render. If I can get my old notebooks working I'll try and give a side by side comparison.
@DavidKutu It does not happen with a regular Python file. As far as I can tell it does not happen with any text file in either vsc or vsc-i.

But to be clear, as far as I can tell, _no_ text file in either vsc or vsc-i scrolls as well as in a native Mac app. One does not have to look far: TextEdit, XCode, or even the Quick Look window in Finder. It's just that the problem as reported here is past the point of acceptability IMO.

I can (now!) open Julia native notebooks in vsc. (I thought that wasn't possible a week ago. Am I confused? The display is different, with different backgrounds and widgets but no syntax coloring in vsc.) In any case, my Julia native notebooks seem to scroll as well in vsc as text scrolls in vsc. Hope this isn't too confusing.

,,

,, 117632,OPEN,outline view,feature-request; outline,2021-02-26 02:40:18 +0000 UTC,ergcode,,,, 117627,OPEN,No need to restart the shell to update path,,2021-02-25 01:50:09 +0000 UTC,jamiehankins,,Issue Type: Feature Request

When you install Visual Studio Code, in the last step, it allows you to add it to various menus, and also to add it to the system path. It says that if you add it to the system path, the shell will have to be restarted for it to take effect.
This is not the case. Instead, you only need to send a WM_SETTINGCHANGE message to all windows using HWND_BROADCAST. When the shell receives that message, it reloads the environment.
Here's my StackOverflow entry for that:

117606,OPEN,[Live Share Web] File Explorer doesn't auto-update on adding a file or folder,,2021-03-08 16:00:28 +0000 UTC,jramsay,,
This is an issue specific to **VS Code Online** so it only repros in **Live Share Web** and not in our desktop extension

Issue: when the Live Share host (on VS Code desktop) adds a file or folder, the guest on _Live Share Web_ does not see it until they manually click the ""Refresh Explorer"" button. It worth noting the issue appears to be specific to add. File or folder rename and delete work correctly - the File Explorer updates automatically and no manual refresh is required.

Our Live Share Web extension has a WorkspaceFileSystemProvider that extends vscode.FileSystemProvider. I've debugged this and can see that when the host adds, deletes, or renames an item, Live Share's file service sends an event that fires **onDidChangeFile.**:
I'm not seeing any of the FileSystemProvider methods get called after the add event fires (Stat, readFile, readDirectory, etc)

I'm unable to debug VS Code minified as for some reason Pretty Print workbench.web.api.js doesn't work anymore on Chrome or Edge (known issue?). I've taken a look at the callstack for Rename events that do refresh correctly and I can see our FileSystemProvider's Stat() gets called from this call stack - so I'm presuming it is going wrong somewhere here for the add event:
1. Host on VS Code Desktop: Sign in and start a Live Share session
2. Guest: Copy the session link directly to Chrome/Edge Chromium browser to join this session with MSA/GitHub accounts.
3. Host: Add a file or folder
The file tree should be refreshed automatically on the guest side
The file tree will update only when refresh it manually
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

117491,OPEN,Wierd White lines appearing all over the workspace,electron; gpu; upstream; windows,2021-03-25 21:14:18 +0000 UTC,srinathvs,,

I am currently using Windows 10 and this started a couple of months ago, but this week, it has become unbearable. The White lines merely used to occlude my file explorer in my workspace, it was annoying and made reading names of files almost impossible, but it was still ok. this week was a new low even for this White line issue. Nhow it started intruding upon my code space, causing even greater issues while I am coding as well, I am not sure what could possibly fix this issue. I can only state that this issue also exists in the epic games launcher.
I am guessing this is an issue with the underlying JS framework and the graphics pipeline of my system not really working together properly.
I am currently using a laptop with integrated and a discrete gpu. This problem is perisistent on windows 10.

The Atom code editor that also works on the same Electron JS framework does not have this issue. I have tried setting the global settings for the gpu being used to automatic and I have tried all the possible fixes listed online, but none have really worked for me.

column1: 117269,OPEN,Can't start extension host process from duplicate workspace windows,,2021-03-25 21:14:07 +0000 UTC,Tpuljak,,"
1. Open a workspace containing an extension in development (Let's call it `workspace  A`).
2. Duplicate the workspace (Command Palette -> Workspaces: Duplicate as Workspace in New Window) (call this `workspace B`)
3. Run the extension from `workspace A`. This opens a new VSCode window that runs the Extension and `workspace A` is debugging it.

4. Run the extension from `workspace B`. This uses the same VSCode window that `workspace A` used and shuts down the `workspace A` debug process. **(Previously `workspace B` would open its own new VSCode instance so the processes would run in parallel in `workspace A` and `workspace B`)**
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported direct to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
I've been developing an extension for the last couple of months and it was very important for me to be able to run parallel extension host processes so they can communicate with each other.

I took a break from developing it since Jan 19th 2021 and returned to it today and discovered this issue. (In the meantime VSCode updated to version 1.53.2 so I presume the issue came with the changes applied with that version)

,,

117208,OPEN,Revisit custom editor input factory,custom-editors; debt; important; workbench-editors,2021-03-23 16:51:45 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,"While working on https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/116856 I spent some though on the custom editor input factory. The only usecase today seems to be for restoring backups (via [`BackupRestorer`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/a830cb5f74e5a487dd8a764c84e1fa38f3e763dd/src/vs/workbench/contrib/backup/common/backupRestorer.ts#L22-L22)).

I would think that a better place for this would be `IEditorService#createEditorInput` and the backup restorer should just use that. If we need to make this method async for a few usecases I think that is OK, as long as the signature could stay sync for most typical uses.
Overall I think we should merge the `ICutomEditorInputFactory` into the existing `IEditorInputFactory` and not have 2 concepts.",,

117207,OPEN,Workbench editor associations should be a generic editor concept or move to custom editors entirely,custom-editors; debt,2021-02-26 00:56:43 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,"While working on https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/116856 I noticed a weird relationship between the `IEditorService`' responsibility of `registerCustomEditorViewTypesHandler`, the fact that `editorOpenWith.ts` manages the `workbench.editorAssociations` setting and the truth that only custom editors and notebooks seem to pick up on the setting.

In https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/116856 I have moved the handling of `workbench.editorAssociations` into `vs/workbench/browser/editor.ts` as an editor associations factory because I felt the editor service was the wrong place for it.

However, if the only client of this setting is the custom editor service, I would suggest to move it somewhere there. And if not, I would suggest to move code of custom editor handling into workbench core. Specifically `CustomEditorInfo` and `selectorMatches` etc.

I think my preference would be to move the factory code into the custom editor contrib and let notebooks use it from there. If you feel strong about moving it back into a service, feel free to add it to custom editor service.

column1: 117189,OPEN,candidatePortSource API sets a user setting,feature-request; remote-explorer,2021-03-22 13:36:30 +0000 UTC,roblourens,,"Was looking into how `candidatePortSource` works for resolvers, and it looks like if Remote-SSH sets it to `Output`, then the setting `""remote.autoForwardPortsSource"": ""output""` is set. If Remote-SSH changed that property, then the setting wouldn't be changed. That probably won't happen but this is confusing from an extension API perspective because a resolver could change that property at any point in it's lifecycle.
I think what I would expect is that the user can set that setting, and it would override what the resolver set, but the resolver's value would only be respected for one vscode remote session.",,

2. Start VS Code and let auto-download try to install extension update.
3. Observe the „Corrupt ZIP: end of central directory record signature not found“ message.
4. Authenticate the proxy in normal browser.
5. Start VS Code and try to install the update again.
6. Immediately you see the „Corrupt ZIP: end of central directory record signature not found“.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported direct to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

The problem is that the invalid file got downloaded and kept in place. I found file `c:\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\Code\CachedExtensionVSIXs\ms-python.python-2021.2.582707922` with the following content:
You will be redirected to a ....
This file was re-used while retrying to update the extension. Even after uninstalling and trying to install the extension again the problem persisted.

Invalid downloaded files could be kept after download for investigation, but they should be re-downloaded when trying to update again. Solution could be to rename the downloaded file to something else (add “corrupted” prefix/suffix) when corruption is detected for example.

117106,OPEN,Advanced wrapping strategy causes hangs for larger files,bug; editor-wrapping; freeze-slow-crash-leak,2021-02-25 09:48:18 +0000 UTC,MicahZoltu,,- VS Code Version: 1.53.2
1. Launch VSCode with extensions disabled, word wrap enabled, and advanced wrapping strategy enabled.
2. Wait for 1 minute 15 seconds and two ""keep waiting"" prompts.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

I searched for issues related to large files but they all seem to imply that the issues were fixed a long time ago and that loading large files *should* work fine today.  Once the file is loaded, everything is snappy **except** resizing the window.  Any attempt to resize the VS Code window will result in an even longer wait time than the initial load.
On my computer (i7-7700 with 64GB of RAM SSD) it takes over a minute to open a 10MB log file.

Given that I have seen other users indicate that (after previous bugfixes and performance improvements) they were able to open files that were hundreds of megabytes, I suspect that what I'm experiencing is unexpected behavior.",,

117077,OPEN,API: one to one mapping between notebook document and kernel,notebook; notebook-kernel; under-discussion,2021-03-18 08:08:45 +0000 UTC,rebornix,,"* 1 to 1 mapping between `NotebookDocument` and `NotebookKernel`
* Kernel is resolved when users want to execute the document/cell. It doesn't require the editor being opened
* When a notebook document is attached to an editor, the kernel provider will get a `comm` object tied to the editor.
* If there are multiple editors for the same document, the kernel provider should get multiple `comm` objects. The kernel is responsible for broadcasting messages to multiple `comm`s

* Execution results, including execution count, state, ellapsed time and outputs are all applied to the `NotebookDocument`, so the changes will be picked up by all editors opened for the same document.",,

117070,OPEN,Fix and consider using the terminal's latency detection code,feature-request; integrated-terminal,2021-02-19 18:06:46 +0000 UTC,Tyriar,,"There is some code in the terminal to enable getting the latency each terminal instance, eg:

The idea here was to measure the time it took to call `getLatency` which itself is a very simple function on `TerminalProcess` that simple returns 0, such that getLatency requests for processes local to the renderer process would simply be 0. This could then feed into type ahead and other features as necessary. So this would measure the latency between the renderer and the TerminalProcess object, not the actual pty.
@TylerLeonhardt, @connor4312 not sure if this is of use in type ahead now but it might be a useful signal.",,

117054,OPEN,Investigate how tunnel package avoids the proxy override,bug; proxy,2021-04-01 16:06:15 +0000 UTC,chrmarti,,"Customer feedback: The HDInsights extension continues using a proxy when HTTP_PROXY and NO_PROXY are set such that no proxy should be used because it depends on packages that do not support NO_PROXY.

We need investigate how the tunnel package avoids our proxy override and improve on it. Should also investigate which package exactly supports HTTP_PROXY, but not NO_PROXY and file an issue for them.",,

117051,OPEN,Extension recommendations as modal dialogs,extensions,2021-03-16 17:26:45 +0000 UTC,isidorn,,"We plan to experiment with showing extension recommendations as modal dialogs after the user explicitly hit the ""Set Language Mode"" action.
This way user will discover extensions easier, and hopefully we will show it in just the right time.
We plan to do it start of march.

`fileBasedRecommendations` listen on `commandService.onDidExecuteCommand` and if you see that the `workbench.action.editor.changeLanguageMode` is exectued and that the mode of the active editor is no longer `plaintext` you show the model dialog, not the notification

117043,OPEN,Should staged colors default to non-staged ones?,,2021-03-10 10:14:33 +0000 UTC,usernamehw,,"At some point new colors were introduced like `gitDecoration.stageModifiedResourceForeground`, bust most color themes have only colors set for ordinary `gitDecoration.modifiedResourceForeground`.
I think staged should default to normal variants unless they are specified.",,
1. Merge something with more than 5000 changed files
2. Have merge conflicts in several files, including files not in the first 5000 changed files
3. VS Code only shows the ones in the first 5000 changed files
The preferred behaviour would be that VS Code shows all conflicts, probably by reducing the number of viewed staged changes

117014,OPEN,Undo/Redo but non-linear,,2021-02-19 13:55:44 +0000 UTC,techsin,,Conceptually it's easy to imagine states as a tree data structure. Every time you make an edit if there is an existing child, then add another, not replace it. So instead of double linked list, it becomes a tree. However, I think what makes it or breaks this feature is the UI.
It's important to not modify undo/redo, but add to it somehow..

2. Same thing as above but in a separate timeline view kinda like git diff view.
2. GUI tree view like git graph but you can click on dots to get history

117013,OPEN,NPM package for vscode-json-languageserver not sync'd with VSCode releases,feature-request; json,2021-02-22 17:11:18 +0000 UTC,mickaelistria,,"The NPM package for vscode-json-languageserver is not sync'd with VSCode release. It was not published for 5 months (mid-September), while the LS received several updates in VSCode source tree and releases.
* In vscode, the vscode-json-languageserver module version is more or less unmaintained. The vscode-json-languageserver is treated as an internal module so version concerns are secondary.
* When VSCode releases, no new release of vscode-json-languageserver seems to happen automatically.

That makes the npm module more or less useless: we tried to adopt it in Wild Web Developer and got missing features, or unexpected older dependencies, conflicting with other LS we ""extract"" from VSCode. As a result, we move back to extracting this JSON Language Server from VSCode.

I think it would be in the best interest of the LSP community if this language server were extracted from VSCode source tree as a standalone NPM module, with proper versioning and published to npm.js. Then consumers (VSCode, Wild Web Developer...) could just install this module with some guarantee of it being up-to-date.
Same pattern could apply to other LS and debug adapters included in VSCode (HTML, CSS).",,

,, 116939,OPEN,Important control characters aren't rendered when ""editor.renderControlCharacters"" is set; possibly leading users astray",editor-rendering; feature-request,2021-03-25 22:11:44 +0000 UTC,fj,,"Issue Type: Bug
Imagine you're looking at some code in VS Code:
Ostensibly, this transfers 6,776 USD from sender 5678 to recipient 1234. Right?
Unfortunately, no. Instead, this code hides malicious intent: **it actually transfers 4,321 USD from sender 5678 to recipient 6776**, stealing sender 5678's money. How is this possible?
It's because this code is hiding two special Unicode control characters: U+202E (""right-to-left override"") and U+202C (""pop directional formatting""). With explicit insertions, it looks like this:

In other words, this gives the code the _visual appearance_ of sending 6776 USD to recipient 1234, but that's not what the _actual underlying text_ says; it says to transfer 4,321 USD to recipient 6776. Our editor — what we trust to show us text correctly — has led us into the wrong conclusion.
We can see that the actual bytes of the string in the code example do indeed have these control characters:

Normally the way around this sort of sneakiness is to use `View > Show Control Characters`. But if you copy the string from the example into VS Code, you won't see these control characters. They aren't rendered at all. How can we make sure these special characters get rendered?

The bug is in `src/vs/editor/common/viewLayout/viewLineRenderer.ts`: it assumes a definition of ""control character"" that amounts to ""anything whose character code as determined by [`String.charCodeAt`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/charCodeAt) is in the range U+0000⋯U+001F"".
That assumption is incorrect, or at least too narrow to cover this case.

The right definition for control character for purposes of VS Code is probably, at a minimum, ""anything in the `Cc` and `Cf` [Unicode general categories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode_character_property#General_Category)"", and not the current definition.

116897,OPEN,Webviews can prevent keyboard shortcuts from working in quick picks,author-verification-requested; bug; webview,2021-03-22 22:59:42 +0000 UTC,tspence,,"
1. Open a full-editor webview in the main editor area
2. Open a text file in the editor
3. Close the text file using a keyboard shortcut (Cmd+W or Ctrl+F4); the full-editor webview should now receive focus
4. Press Cmd+P to open the quick-pick file selector
5. Select a file from the quick pick editor; VS Code will jump you to that file
6. While editing this file, press Cmd+P again to open the quick-pick file selector
* I can use keyboard shortcuts for Cut / Copy / Paste while in the quick pick editor
* All keyboard shortcuts are disabled in this quick pick window.

During step 5 of the reproduction, VS Code switches focus to the code file you selected from the quick pick.  Additionally, a delayed action fires as the quick pick closes.  The delayed action tells the system to return focus to the element that previously had focus, which was the full-editor webview.
The full-editor webview thinks it has focus, and as a result it absorbs all cut/copy/paste commands that are defined in webview.contribution.ts.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

116881,OPEN,support absolute path in markdown preview custom stylesheet,feature-request; markdown,2021-02-26 02:07:18 +0000 UTC,alexsong19,,```
Now, this doesn't seem to work. You can only use a relative path to your current project.

This creates headaches. One uses markdown to take notes, and these notes are in many different folders. The current way requires you to have a .css file floating around in each of these folders containing your notes. Everytime I create a markdown file in a new folder, I have to copy the .css file to that folder. If I don't have the .css file in that project folder, vscode will complain every step of the way as I type in the markdown file.

The current way doesn't make philosophical sense either. The setting is a _global_ setting, yet its content is with respect to each project differently. For a global setting, why not allowing it to look for an absolute path?",,

,, 116840,OPEN,[html] handle HTML-escaped characters in links,bug; html,2021-02-22 15:20:03 +0000 UTC,rjgotten,,Issue Type: Bug
Given trivial HTML or XML content that contains a url with a valid entity escape code:
The clickable hyperlink directs the user to `https://www.example.com/foo.html?bar&baz`
The clickable hyperlink directs the user to a corrupted version of the url.
The type of corruption differs between XML and HTML document contexts.
`&` is left verbatim and the clickable link directs the user to `https://www.example.com/foo.html?bar&baz`.
the `&` in the `&` HTML entity is double-escaped using percentage encoding and the user is directed to` https://www.example.com/foo.html?bar%26amp%3Bbaz`.

Not just limited to HTML or XML documents. Can confirm that among other things, this _also_ breaks `<seealso href=""..."" />` type links in C# XMLDoc. Both the in-document clickable link _and_ the link rendered in the popup documentation tooltip.

column1: 116834,OPEN,adding mouse wheel event support for extension development,feature-request,2021-04-10 02:34:34 +0000 UTC,computHome,,"mouse wheel event could be more useful than keystroke in many circumstances:

control/shift + wheel down - to find next word found

116827,OPEN,[FR] Settings to make find-and-replace work like Notepad++,feature-request,2021-02-24 02:41:07 +0000 UTC,BeeePollen,,
1). Maintain any selection in the editor regardless of any operations related to find-and-replace.
2). Automatically repeat the ""find in selection"" process whenever the find-and-replace interface is opened.
3). Automatically repeat the ""find in selection"" process whenever the selection is changed while the find-and-replace interface is open.
4). Make the ""replace"" operation apply only to the current selection, rather than to all lines intersecting the current selection.
5). Do not replace the ""find"" term with the current selection when opening the find-and-replace interface.
- When I say ""find-and-replace,"" I mean the ctrl+h thing.
- When I say 'repeat the ""find in selection"" process', I mean mimic the behavior of toggling find-and-replace in selection to ""on,"" except observing 1) and 5)).

Item 5) is already possible by itself, but I don't think the other 4 can currently be achieved. At least two of the others have been discussed (e.g. [2)](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/95356), [4)](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/107182)). But I think that these requests, taken together, make find-and-replace work the way that many other users expect, especially new boring corporate users like me.
If I explained everything correctly, this is how it works by default in Notepad++, SQL Server Management Studio, and Excel's VBA editor.",,
116812,OPEN,Menubar access keys are not underlined in native titlebar mode,electron; menus; titlebar; upstream; windows,2021-02-23 04:21:26 +0000 UTC,JohnKlenk,,"Issue Type: Bug
When using the ""native"" titlebar option, the menubar access keys are not underlined until you press the Alt key.  It should honor the Windows setting for whether to underline access keys.
Really frustrating that in order to be able to see when the app has focus (by using the native titlebar), I can't see the underlined menu items, which is a huge pet peeve.

116755,OPEN,Source control: improve focus movement,accessibility,2021-02-16 08:56:45 +0000 UTC,isidorn,,"I did some improvements in the `ActionBar` focus which I think reflect positively in the SCM view.
However there is still two corner cases which I think we could improve:
1. Focus onto an element in Changes view, press `tab` -> focus jump to inline actions (great)
2. Press `shit + tab` -> focus is moved to the Message box 🐛
It would be cool if `tab` and `shift+tab` are always paired, thus `shift+tab` after a `tab` would bring you back to the original item.
1. Focus onto the first item in changes
2. Press `shift + tab` -> focus is moved in title bar actions 🐛
3. I would expect the focus to move into the commit box
Overall I think the focus navigation in SCM works nice, thanks to this ""top level"" up and down navigation which allows to focus into something.

116752,OPEN,Source control: do not show action bar for selected but only for focused items,,2021-02-16 10:55:21 +0000 UTC,isidorn,,"Currently in SCM we render the hidden action bar when an item has focus, hover or if it is selected.
This is unlike other view where we render the action bar only when an item has focus or is hovered.
I suggest that we change the SCM to behave like the other views.
Apart from consistency this should also improve focus navigation
fyi @joaomoreno to see if he did this behaviour on purpose

This issue aims to explore what adding ""profiles"" could look like in the product. These profiles can be used in education, presentations, or can even be language specific. The explorations should cover being able to setup and switch between profiles. Ideally these profiles should be synced with [Settings Sync](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/settings-sync) (if used) so you can use those profiles anywhere.
One idea for settings is to introduce a new settings object like:

The ""Demos"" profile inherits the current settings a user has and adds additional settings on top of the current ones. Also, when profiles are enabled we will create a ""Default"" profile where the user can switch back to their default mode.
- Multiple environment profiles (either per-session or per-window) #57548

Currently each debug session must be initiated form vscode side. Is there a way it could be achieved that when the extension receives a valid DBGP debug connection it somehow starts a new DebugSession and passes the connected socket over to that one?

116729,OPEN,The INI file Extension is sometimes using the wrong comment character.,,2021-03-31 18:40:19 +0000 UTC,djbusby,,- Chrome: 83.0.4103.122
1.  Open an INI type file, typically has the `.ini` extension.
2.  Use the keyboard shortcut to add a comment character.
3. Sometimes (and I can't figure out why) it will insert the CORRECT comment character of `;` but on other occasions it chooses a `#`

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No, if I disable the INI extension (which is part of core) then the commenting parts don't work at all for either the ""INI"" or the ""properties"" type of files.
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported direct to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

I've noticed that in  `ini.language-configuration.json` and `properties.language-configuration.json` there are different comments (""lineComment"").   In the `ini.` file it's indicating `;` and in the `properties.` file it's shown as a `#`   Even when VSCode indicator is showing ""INI"" type the value from the `properties.` file is being selected.

For me this is not happening 100% of the time.  Some files it will properly select semi-colon.  Other files it will select the hash-mark.  VSCode will even select the hash character even in a file that is already commented with semi-colon.  Additionally, sometimes VSCode will select a different character than last time.  That is.  I start fresh VSCode instance and edit ""example.ini"" from scratch; and semi-colon is automatically selected.  Close VSCode. Start Fresh open example.ini; using the keyboard shortcut to comment this time is hash.  And at a later session it might be back to using semi-colon.

116726,OPEN,Community Question regarding Issue Handling,,2021-02-25 23:14:43 +0000 UTC,plainerman,,Over the last few weeks, I have started regularly contributing to VSCode and helping where I can. But I have seen some issues / PRs that have been left unanswered and have been abandoned due to no response. This could lead to a large backlog, taking a lot of time to maintain, and (speaking from personal experience) can discourage the community members from involving.
Of course, we are all in hurry sometimes (or forget things, are on holiday, sick-leave …), but I was wondering about the team’s perspective on this topic.

Is there a document / section in the wiki that describes a procedure on what a community member can / should do in cases where a discussion in an issue is left unanswered? Or more importantly, there is no reaction on a PR from the assignee? Surely there cannot be one *right* solution, as this varies strongly from case to case, but a general guideline would be very helpful in my opinion.
From the top of my head, specifically the following questions arise:
* Is there a (rough) estimate on how long one should wait before pinging an assignee again, when a question etc. has been left unanswered? A week? two weeks?

* What can / should one do, when an assignee does not respond anymore, and pings don’t seem to help? Is there anyone that can be involved in this case to further pursue the issue / PR (e.g. mentioning the person responsible for inbox tracking this week)?
* What to do with existing issues that do not have an assignee anymore?

If there is already a documentation about this, I would suggest linking this in the *How-to-Contribute* section in the wiki. If not, and the procedure is explained to me, I would be happy to add it myself (or maybe even add a link to this issue).
If this is not the correct place to discuss such things, please point me in the right direction. Thanks :)

column1: 116673,OPEN,Source Control does not refresh status automatically when working on WSL.,,2021-02-16 12:24:26 +0000 UTC,Suyash1266,,"Issue Type: Bug

Whenever any changes are made to a already committed file or a new file is created or basically any changes are made in a git repository not from the source control GUI, the changes made are not synced with VS Code Explorer and need to hit refresh manually to see changes such as U or M tags in the file explorer or file tab.
1. Open any git repository on WSL.
2. Create a new file or edit any previously committed file.
Expected Result - The changes should be synced with Source Control and tags should change accordingly to M or U automatically.

Actual Result - Nothing happens. The clock symbol on source control appears for less than a second when a new file is created from the explorer but still nothing happens. The clock does not even show when creating files from the terminal. Changes are visible on the source control tab only after hitting refresh manually.
Does it work with extensions disabled - Unable to verify. When loaded without extensions the WSL side asks to enable WSL-Remote extension and reload. After reload all extensions get enabled.
PS: This issue does not occur on the windows side of VS Code when working on the same repo and using WSL as terminal. Works as expected.

column1: 116664,OPEN,Bash command to clear the VSCode integrated terminal scrollback on Windows 10?,integrated-terminal; under-discussion,2021-02-19 17:44:25 +0000 UTC,denishowe,,"Issue Type: Bug
I'm happily running [Git](https://git-scm.com/download/win) bash in VSCode on Windows with:

The ""Terminal: Clear"" command (`workbench.action.terminal.clear`, which I have bound to Control-L) clears not only the screen but also the scrollback buffer, as expected, so trying to scroll up does nothing because there is nothing to show.
How can I reproduce this with a shell command?

The `clear` command does not clear the scrollback, neither does `reset`. These commands work by outputting escape sequences to the screen.  Since the terminal thinks it is ""TERM = xterm-256color"", the relevant escape sequence should be the one output by the shell command `printf ""\e[3J""` which works on all other xterm emulations (and is part of `clear`'s output).  In VSCode it does not clear the scrollback but, oddly, resurrects one screenful of previously cleared scrollback.

116487,OPEN,Dot notation support for breadcrumb navigation,breadcrumbs; feature-request,2021-02-12 08:19:44 +0000 UTC,ppicom,,+ _Board_

Moreover, when focused on this breadcrumbs menu **you can start typing the name of the element you want to go to**, and press enter to go there. It is great, but **it only works as long as that element is already visible** in the drop-down menu.
Following with my example, this means that I can't start typing _""constr""_ to got to Game's constructor or Square's constructor (nor to any of its methods).
So, to make the breadcrumbs feature more awesome **I'd like to suggest to make it compatible with dot notation**.
This way, I could start typing ""Game.constr"" to go to that element independently from where my cursor is at the moment or which elements are unfolded in the drop-down menu.
Following again the example, let's suppose I want to go to the constructor of the `Game` class. I press ""**Ctrl + Shift+ .**"" and type _""Game.constr""_. The logic I find best would be:
1. Is _""Game.constr""_ an actual element I can go to? (current behavior)
2. If not, is _""Game""_ an element in the current scope?
1.  If it is, has such element a child which name starts with _""constr""_?
2. Yeah? Go there and end use case.
3. If not, is ""Game"" an element in the root of the source file
1. Has such element a child which name starts with _""constr""_?
2. Yeah? Go there and end use case.
4. If not, the element wasn't found. End of use case.",,

116454,OPEN,Search view focus should be improved,accessibility; feature-request,2021-03-24 00:27:13 +0000 UTC,isidorn,,"1. Open search viewlet, make sure to have the replace also open
2. Press `tab` a couple of times and notice how the focus moves
I understand that this focus movement is designed behaviour since users expect the first tab from the search input to go to the replace input and I think it makes sense.

However there is a lot of very custom code to make this possible. Listening on `tab` presses [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/a0bbfacd8cfeeaebc1c5bd49bb7ffdfb804c4b5b/src/vs/workbench/contrib/search/browser/searchWidget.ts#L556).

This milestone I am trying to change how the `ActionBar` focus navigation works and this would include the search input inline checkbox actions - even though as an implementation they do not use an `ActionBar` they should behave consistently. I would like to make those checkboxes occupy only one tab stop and that users can use `left` and `right` to move focus between them - just like we now do in all `ActionBars`.
I tried changing this in Search however due to the custom focus handling code this proved to be a bit complex.
What I am suggestion is the following tab flow:

Search Input `->` Replace Input `->` Search inline actions `->` Replace inline Actions `->` Toggle Search Details `->` Files to Include `->` Files To Include Inline Actions `->` Files To Exclude `->` Files to Exclude inline actions
Let me know what you think and how you think is the best way to proceed
the color coding of the code is not working in my c++ files

116420,OPEN,Explore fine grained semantic searching of symbols inside breadcrumbs view,editor-symbols; feature-request,2021-04-05 02:34:59 +0000 UTC,aszenz,,"I think navigating code using breadcrumbs can be improved a lot by incorporating some kind of searching inside the breadcrumbs view.
Here's how i think it might work:

> When I'm inside a method symbol and it's showing me all the symbols inside that method, when I search for `foo`, it should highlight and scroll down to the first symbol named `foo` in that method so i can easily go to it's definition or just see the surrounding symbols around it. Even more useful is if can jump between foo's usages in that particular method.
**This enables quickly jumping to variables and their usages inside a function using structured semantic search.**
>Same goes for files, searching for a file inside a breadcrumb directory should take me straight to where the first match is, even if the file is deeply nested.
_It's important that the list be not filtered by the filename rather only expanded with matching highlights so that I don't lose the context of where the file is located._
**This will  make it easier to find and jump between files in that directory.**

The interesting part about this is that the existing symbol search using `@` in command bar is already searchable, but it's completely flat and can't do fine grained semantic searching so it's rarely used to navigate code.

The overall goal should be to allow people to navigate their code bases using symbols and not text, this necessitates being able to find and go to symbols in a more fine grained manner than currently possible in vs code.
At a higher level it's about traversing the constructed language server's AST in a flexible fine grained manner.

I think a new kind of view maybe required for this, a multi level drop down with built in search that can auto expand and highlight searched items even if they are deeply nested inside the drop down tree.
**Also this can be separate from the existing breadcrumbs view and more likely be built as a new semantic symbol search view.**",,

116418,OPEN,Go to next line (move the caret one line down independent of word wrap),editor-commands; feature-request,2021-03-12 18:08:56 +0000 UTC,mstenemo,,This is slightly different from the recently added prevBlankLine and nextBlankLine cursorMove command (Insiders' Build for v1.54) for moving between code blocks like in [Sublime](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45788119/is-there-a-vs-code-shortcut-to-move-select-up-down-to-the-next-empty-line/66066852#66066852) and [Emacs](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61628527/how-can-i-add-emacs-like-control-up-down-to-vscode).,,

116413,OPEN,Diff inside a single line: make changes easier to see,,2021-04-08 08:25:20 +0000 UTC,kaba2,,That's right, a single comma inside the paragraph was added. However, diff visualizes it as if the whole paragraph were changed.

If you look very closely, you'll notice that that comma is actually marked with a lighter color. So Code does know where the change occurs inside a line. However, that lighter color is very difficult to distinguish from the surrounding color.
**Make it so that changes inside a single line can be seen quickly, at a glance.**
I'm not sure what the best approach for that is, but I'll mention a few possibilities in increasing level of hardness:
1) Change the color of the inside-line changes so that they really pop out from the color of the line. Like this:
2) Restrict the line-coloring to the left sidebar. Use coloring inside a line to locate the changes. Like this:
4) Actually, shouldn't the diff just work inside a single line? Like this:
P.S. Many thanks for the recent word wrap functionality in the diff view! It makes reviewing changes to Latex text much simpler.",,

116337,OPEN,Sandbox background process architecture,sandbox; under-discussion,2021-02-17 05:38:29 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,From discussion today in standup here are suggestions for the sandbox architecture:
* leverage the existing shared process as much as possible (make it robust, start fast and have logging for crashes)
* keep main process usage as little as possible
* aggressively move things over to shared process (e.g. logger, sqlite?)

* investigate into turning the shared process into a lightweight node.js process with `MessagePort` support and access to Electron's proxy solution for network requests (if we cannot get proxy support here, we could think about doing ad-hoc hidden windows for network requests as a workaround)

,,

column1: 116150,OPEN,Extension API: Provide a way to add commands to menus in the Mac main menu bar,,2021-02-08 23:44:16 +0000 UTC,shepazon,,"* **Categorization**; allowing new menus to be specified by the user, then allowing extension commands to be added to these menus, lets the user categorize these commands as they see fit. They could even have per-workspace configurations that set up menus with the special scripts used just for each project.
If the concern is about user security, I have ideas:
* Extensions should not be able to alter the built-in menus
* The user, not the extension, should define what menus to add to the menu bar and what goes into them.

This could be done using a new setting such as `workbench.menubar` which is essentially an array of objects that describe each custom menu added to the menu bar. Each menu would have a name, any state information needed, and an array of objects describing the contents of the menu.

These objects would specify the command represented by the item, plus a text label for the menu (or `null` to use the command's name), enabled/disabled state, checkmark state, and so forth. Most other information can come from the command's existing implementation.
I think this could provide incredible flexibility for the user while ensuring safety and security.",,

116141,OPEN,Allow TreeItem's to have optional checkboxes,api-proposal; feature-request; tree-widget,2021-04-01 14:48:33 +0000 UTC,TylerLeonhardt,,#### Scenarios
* Applying filters where an 'Edit' button drops you into the experience above where checkboxes show up
* Crafting `.gitignore`'s or other 'ignores' where you go down the filesystem and uncheck the files you want to ignore
* TreeItem has new optional property called `checkboxState` similar to `collapsibleState` which takes in a `TreeItemCheckBoxState`:
* Checkbox state of the tree item
* Determines an item can be neither checked nor unchecked. Implies it has no checkbox.
* `TreeDataProvider` will have a new optional event `onDidChangeTreeCheckbox` which will fire when the checkbox of a `TreeItem` is checked or unchecked:
* A data provider that provides tree data
* An optional event to signal that an element or root has either been checked or unchecked.
* The item that was checked or unchecked.

116064,OPEN,Extension API: workspace folders vs git repositories not consistent regarding symlinks,bug; git,2021-02-08 19:55:29 +0000 UTC,letmaik,,The paths in the git extension's `API.repositories` do have their symlinks resolved.
This seems inconsistent and makes life hard if you want to easily check the relation between the two paths.

It seems the git extension itself gets confused by this and shows the full path in the SCM view if the repo/workspace folder is in a symlinked folder. Notably, the file watcher also doesn't resolve symlinks.
I think the paths returned from the git extension should not have their symlinks resolved so that they can be easily compared with all the other paths from vs code.",,

column1: 116029,OPEN,Integrated terminal in WSL does not wrap to newline when command is long.,bug; integrated-terminal; remote,2021-04-06 20:24:47 +0000 UTC,Waghabond,,"We have written the needed data into your clipboard because it was too large to send. Please paste.

This problem is exclusive to the cmd and bash terminals (powershell doesn't have it). It also only happens when thhe vscode window is opened in WSL using the Remote-WSL extension. The bash and cmd shells wrap lines properly if the current vscode window is not connected to WSL.

The problem is that when these conditions are met (vscode is connected to WSL and the shell being used in the integrated terminal is bash or cmd). If a command exceeds the length of the terminal window the terminal doesnt make a new line, it glitches and starts overwriting the same line from the start of the window. The command still works fine but its a visual bug.

115960,OPEN,Option to Specify Line Height as a Multiple of Font Size,editor-core; feature-request,2021-03-25 21:35:07 +0000 UTC,cpsauer,,Small usability tweak request:
It'd be really nice to be able to specify editor line height as a multiple of font size.
Pitch for why it's worth considering:
- It'd be more consistent with the other line height settings in VSCode. (markdown.preview.lineHeight and terminal.integrated.lineHeight are both multipliers--only editor.lineHeight is absolute).
-  It would also unbreak dynamically resizing code on the fly, which is often important while communicating, like in teaching.

- Seems like lots of people change this setting, since [VSCode's spacing default](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/23806) is significantly bigger than most editors and people like seeing lots of code on the page. And [this leads to confusion](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/33968) because most line spacing settings are a multiplier, in VSCode and elsewhere.

Being able to (optionally) specify the value in ems would solve the problem, while remaining backwards compatible. To give concrete examples, ""15"" could remain a valid value (implicitly in pixels), but 1.25em could also be a valid value that would rescale properly if the text size were changed.
Thank you for your consideration--and a truly excellent piece of software!",,

115958,OPEN,Are there any plans to create ultra stable native version of vscode?,,2021-02-08 09:28:39 +0000 UTC,techsin,,"I'm proposing to create non-electron highly performant native version of vscode which gets new release once a year.
Basically sync stabilized features from electron version into native annually.
Only reason would be extreme performance. As vscode more and more becomes IDE like, performance struggles are starting to show up...
- right clicks seem to take longer
- input latency seems to be noticeable
- color encoding / parsing takes a moment
Don't take me wrong it's by far one of the most performant code editors i've used.
But lot of the things mentioned seem to add up. I personally notice this most when I go from coding on laptop to desktop.
I'd love to know if there are plans, and if yes, i'd love to cast a vote in favor or contribute somehow. ",,

115949,OPEN,Support additional buffers or layers in xterm,feature-request; integrated-terminal; integrated-terminal-local-echo,2021-02-12 23:41:30 +0000 UTC,connor4312,,"The typeahead/local echo implementation we have now is more complex than it needs to be and supports a smaller subset of functionality that it could. This is because, in order to validate predictions, we manually parse input character-by-character and see how to process it and whether we need to roll predictions back.

mosh handles typeahead differently: they keep an ""overlay"" buffer that hold predictions and is separate from the buffer that is made up of data from the pty. This allows them to simply apply incoming data unchanged, and then validate data in the overlay versus that in the real buffer. If a character in the overlay is now present in the real buffer, remove it from the overlay. If it's different, just clear the overlay. This removes a ton of complexity that we have now to deal with rolling back and rolling forwards and tracking style changes.

It also means that we would get support for more complex scenarios, like powershell which rewrites the entire line on each character, for 'free' -- no additional complexity in our algorithm, that is. @TylerLeonhardt's been working on getting powershell working with our current approach and is ending up in a series of edge cases and rabbit holes.",,

115808,OPEN,Proposal for updating commenting area for diffs,comments; diff-editor; feature-request; ux,2021-02-05 18:46:06 +0000 UTC,misolori,,I was exploring ways to improve the PR experience in VS Code and one of the ideas involved updating the glyph area for comments. Currently we show a gray bar and a unicode `+` and `♦` that don't look very pretty.
A couple of things I explored:
- Moving glyph area to the left of line numbers. This helps create separation between between the scm indicators and a clear area for adding comments.
- Adding button for adding and view comments. This follows a similar pattern on GitHub for reviewing changes.
- Hiding diff chunk areas. This reduces the visual noise and I think most people will be commenting on changed lines in the PR as opposed to lines that are not related
- Adding color to the `+` and `-` changes to look visually pleasing
Unsure who should I assign to so assigning to @rebornix and @alexdima for now",,

115679,OPEN,Don't leak RPC objects from API,debt,2021-02-05 09:52:25 +0000 UTC,jrieken,,"This is a continuation of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/115530 and an effort to make our API implementation more strict/locked-down.

Most of our API is implemented with the help of RPC calls to the renderer - that can be retrieving data or doing something. This is implemented with a protocol instance and objects that represent a slice of the API, aka proxies, like `MainThreadTextEditorsShape`. These proxies usually mirror the capabilities of the API but are often more powerful and therefore we should make sure these objects cannot be reached from the API.

These leakages usually occur when having an API implemented as object which holds API-properties _and_ internal/private-properties. Since non-native private properties aren't hidden to consumers an extension can reach them.
There are usually two ways of fixing this

1. Use a native private property - that is a property which name starts with `#`. Those properties aren't accessible to outsiders but you should know that TypeScript down-level compiles native privates to a construct that uses weak map and is therefore significantly slower. This is a sample commit that hides a proxy by using a native private property: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/a01d16e77e9b7c7f200d6010b78b519e05913d73

1. A **better** approach is to not mix API and implementation into a single class/function-scope but to separate them. c399d039a71998e8cef312a8584851a03c8f2f64 is a sample for that, instead of mixing things the `NotebookEditorDecorationType`-type has now a `value`-property which is the API. All internals are hidden inside the containing class/scope. This has an additional benefit of TypeScript checking that your API isn't too large, e.g when using a literal for a certain API-type then the compiler will check that you have no extra properties. In the sample above having the `NotebookEditorDecorationType.value.notDeclaredAPI :string`-property yield in a compile error.

To test this I have added the [`assertNoRpcFromEntry`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/a0c75f60530da98fbccf796a7c78c23a7ca168d3/extensions/vscode-api-tests/src/utils.ts#L80-L80) and [`assertNoRpc`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/a0c75f60530da98fbccf796a7c78c23a7ca168d3/extensions/vscode-api-tests/src/utils.ts#L76-L76) utilities which recursively crawl an API object and assert that no RPC object can be reached.
These utilities run during teardown and on objects the API creates, like a status bar entry item. The checking for leaked RPC object does depend therefore on test coverage.",,

column1: 115641,OPEN,Design exploration for improving experience for new users,under-discussion; ux,2021-04-06 21:21:24 +0000 UTC,misolori,,"## Overview
This design exploration aims to improve the overall experience for new users while also providing value for existing users. Going through feedback from new and existing users we've heard that:
- Activity bar icons can sometimes be hard to understand if not familiar with them
- Some features (like the command palette and terminal) are hard to discover
We also wanted to take the opportunity to explore updating the overall aesthetics like:
Below is an example of this exploration. Here's a few ideas that we tried:
- Adding labels to the activity bar
- Moving account/settings to the top right
- Introducing an omni search to include commands, files, tasks, etc. (also combining text search into this)
- Introducing a ""density"" toggle (similar to email clients)
- Introducing a Terminal toggle in the status bar

Here's the feedback I've received on this concept from our team. I'll break down the concepts into individual issue for those we are interested in pursuing more. Note: since this concept touches several ideas at once, it would be good to break down some changes (like density changes and showing more/less UI should be separate).
- Friendlier activity bar labels for new users
- Omni search helps discoverability of command palette/search
- Moving settings/accounts in title bar helps separate views from menus
- Consistent spacing makes for a uniform UI
- Could be too advanced for new users
- Takes up title bar space (will need to look into OS guidelines)
- Need to evaluate relationship between Quick Open + Command Palette
- Can take up dragging real estate for title bar
- Could be costly to maintain two designs w/ density mode
- Some prefer settings/accounts in activity bar
Happy to hear any additional feedback others have on this concept.",,
115626,OPEN,Microsoft Auth Provider should support overriding client id and tenant id,api-proposal; authentication,2021-03-24 01:34:27 +0000 UTC,TylerLeonhardt,,"

As an extension author, I should easily be able to create my own AAD application (in the Azure Portal for example) and use that client id instead of the one vscode uses so that I can have control over the scopes I care about and, if this exists, I can get telemetry when my client id is used.

Since we have abstracted auth providers, I think it's fitting to be able to pass additional auth provider specific options down to an auth provider. For example, the Microsoft auth provider would take a client id and tenant that would replace the hard coded string above.
* Options to be used when getting an [AuthenticationSession](#AuthenticationSession) from an [AuthenticationProvider](#AuthenticationProvider).
* Whether login should be performed if there is no matching session.
* If true, a modal dialog will be shown asking the user to sign in. If false, a numbered badge will be shown
* on the accounts activity bar icon. An entry for the extension will be added under the menu to sign in. This
* allows quietly prompting the user to sign in.
* Whether the existing user session preference should be cleared.
* For authentication providers that support being signed into multiple accounts at once, the user will be
* prompted to select an account to use when [getSession](#authentication.getSession) is called. This preference
* is remembered until [getSession](#authentication.getSession) is called with this flag.
* Provider specific options for getting this session (i.e. client id, tenant)
The Auth Provider would then need to be responsible for deciding if it already has created a session with these options or if it needs to create a new session based on these options.",,

115616,OPEN,Provide extension API to exclude ports from forwarding,api; api-proposal; feature-request; ghcs-in-progress; remote-explorer,2021-03-23 14:23:45 +0000 UTC,alexr00,,From @weinand:
Today the tunneling service blindly forwards all communication ports.
This includes ports that are used for debugging (even if our remote debugging feature does not need these ports to be forwarded).
This is confusing for users because they see ports that they are not really interested in.
I propose to add extension API so that individual ports or port ranges can be excluded from forwarding.
Debug extensions could use this API.

,,
115614,OPEN,XMLHttpRequest's using Git WebView Resource return unexpected result,,2021-02-02 18:57:09 +0000 UTC,bersbersbers,,TLDR: `XMLHttpRequest` inside a WebView on a Git link like
does not provide a valid pdf file, but plain text from `git diff` instead.
You should see something like this:
warning: CRLF will be replaced by LF in dummy.pdf.
The file will have its original line endings in your working directory
+  This is a small demonstration .pdf file -
+  just for use in the Virtual Mechanics tutorials. More text. And more
+  text. And more text. And more text. And more text.
You will now see this - this is the bug described in https://github.com/tomoki1207/vscode-pdfviewer/issues/70
To see what the problem is:
6. Open `%USERPROFILE%\.vscode\extensions\tomoki1207.pdf-1.1.0\lib\build\pdf.js` (`$HOME/.vscode-server/extensions/tomoki1207.pdf-1.1.0/lib/build/pdf.js` for Remote SSH server on Linux)
7. Add `console.log(this.url, xhr);` before line 12738 (`const chunk = getArrayBuffer(xhr);`); save and reload as needed
8. Go to source control view again
11. Expand `XMLHttpRequest` in the console windows that just opened.
You will see two requests like this:

Note the `response` for the second being only 16 bytes long, while the first is >3000 bytes. The first (`37, 80, 68, 70, 45, 49, 46, 51, 13, 10, 37 ...`) is basically `%PDF-1.3...`, a valid PDF header - while the second (`68, 117, 109, 109, 121, 32, 80, 68, 70, 32, 102, 105, 108, 101, 10, 12`) is `Dummy PDF file`. This is exactly what `git diff` shows above. I feel the WebView resource resolver should provide the full `pdf` file, not just its text.",,
115613,OPEN,Terminal steals CTRL+V after launching a C# project that uses console:integratedTerminal,,2021-02-02 15:12:11 +0000 UTC,rjgotten,,"

After launching a C# project with the `""console"":""integratedTerminal""` configuration property set in `launch.json` the VSCode integrated terminal starts stealing _all_ `[CTRL]+[V]` keychords - i.e. the basic paste operation - that should go into the focused editor window.
Can only be fixed by finding the offending terminal, focusing it, and then unfocusing it again.

column1: 115607,OPEN,editor.detectIndentation:false not working properly for .go files,,2021-02-02 15:10:51 +0000 UTC,pprokopi,,"    VSCode Version:code --version 1.48.2
Create a .go file with a separate editor that has tab indentation
Set the following in user settings
Make sure the workspace has no settings
Check in the lower right corner if indentation is tabs or spaces
VS code ignores the already used indentation in the file and uses spaces for future indentation.
VS code detected the indentation of the file and kept using tabs instead of spaces for indentation.
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
115591,OPEN,Custom editors: respect `soft` option when reverting,bug; custom-editors,2021-03-22 22:54:35 +0000 UTC,bpasero,,"I noticed how here we pass in `IRevertOptions` but do not respect them:
The idea of `IRevertOptions.soft` is to really not throw an error because it will prevent an editor from closing when the user clicks ""Don't save"".
I suggest to implement the `soft` revert in a way that we do NOT talk to the extension but simply do everything on the internal workbench side to clean things up and return immediately.
We call `soft: true` for `revert` here when the normal `revert` fails:

115566,OPEN,Mark same keybindings - Badge with the number of same keybinding,feature-request; keybindings-editor,2021-03-05 02:45:42 +0000 UTC,lukaszpolowczyk,,An example of a mockup with a green badge:
The green badge says there are two Command that use the same keyboard shortcut - `selectPartOfWord.moveLeft` and `workbench.action.moveEditorToPreviousGroup`.
The advantage is that you can see the same keybindings right away, you don't need to click ""Show Same Keybindings"" for each Command.
**Additional idea**: Filter ""Show only Commands with Same Keybindings"".",,
115560,OPEN,workspaceFolderBasename variable in settings.json is not set initially,bug; integrated-terminal,2021-02-02 22:29:11 +0000 UTC,geneing,,"
In order to avoid multiple remote tmux sessions, I set in settings.json the following

I expect that workspaceFolderBasename variable contains valid value. However, initally or after window reload this variable is not set. It is only set correctly after I switch source code tabs or open a file.
This is a problem when using remote sessions, because this happens  every time I reconnect to the remote session and VSCode tells me to reload window.

column1: 115559,OPEN,Don't delete Line Feeds in Column mode deletes.,editor-columnselect; feature-request,2021-02-03 14:28:35 +0000 UTC,mrmsbarnes,,"

It's probably too late, but I request a change to Column Mode editing (Shift, Alt, Click, Drag).  When a Line Feed is in a column selected, it should not be deleted on Delete.  This removes empty lines that editors will most-often want to remain.  This is also more like notepad++ column mode editing which I think got it right.
